question: When can an Authorised Person apply a 0% risk weight to CR Exposures to central governments or central banks in the GCC, and how should they treat similar exposures to sovereign PSEs in the UAE and GCC?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person can apply a 0% risk weight to CR Exposures to central governments or central banks in the GCC if these exposures are denominated and funded in the domestic currency of the GCC member country [#TGT:0b38a29a-6f32-46d4-b772-9682878dc7c1]. Individual Emirates of the UAE are treated as GCC member countries for this purpose [#TGT:0b38a29a-6f32-46d4-b772-9682878dc7c1]. For sovereign PSEs in the UAE and GCC with Credit Risks similar to their central government, the exposures must be treated according to Rule 4.12.5 if they meet the denomination and funding requirements [#SRC:81df5980-d082-4e25-8462-5f45542ef806]. If not, Rule 4.12.6(1) applies [#SRC:81df5980-d082-4e25-8462-5f45542ef806].

debug_context.source_text: In (1), sovereign PSEs in the UAE and GCC that exhibit Credit Risks comparable to their central government must be treated in accordance with the requirements set out in Rule 4.12.5, where they meet the requirements in relation to the denomination and funding of the CR Exposure, otherwise they must be treated in accordance with Rule 4.12.6(1).
debug_context.target_text: Central government and central bank asset class. An Authorised Person may apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to central governments or central banks of a GCC member country which are denominated and funded in the domestic currency of the GCC member country. For the purposes of this Rule, individual Emirates of the UAE will be considered as though they were GCC member countries.

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator require the payment of a supplementary fee for the filing of a Supplementary Prospectus, and how does this relate to other applications or authorisations?
expected_answer: The Regulator may require the payment of a supplementary fee for the filing of a Supplementary Prospectus if the review necessitates substantial additional costs or effort [#SRC:cec237a1-c364-4ed0-9197-dcac6160defb]. This condition aligns with the broader context where the Regulator may impose supplementary fees for any application, authorisation, or ongoing supervision if substantial additional costs or effort are expected [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080].

debug_context.source_text: The filing of a Supplementary Prospectus does not trigger the payment of a fee unless the review of the Supplementary Prospectus will require the Regulator to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort when conducting its review, in which event the Regulator may require payment of a supplementary fee in accordance with Rule 1.2.4.
debug_context.target_text: Supplementary fees The Regulator may require a Person to pay to the Regulator a supplementary fee in circumstances where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing or when conducting on-going supervision.

question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator issue a direction to a Recognised Body concerning its Controllers, and what factors will the Regulator consider in determining the appropriateness of exercising such powers?
expected_answer: The Regulator may issue a direction to a Recognised Body concerning its Controllers if it deems the direction desirable to advance one or more of its operational objectives [#TGT:1c3cd986-8007-416b-9fb1-e4600d1b1c81]. In determining the appropriateness of exercising such powers, the Regulator will consider all relevant information and factors, including the Rules contained in MIR, the results of its routine supervision of the Recognised Body, and the extent to which any failure or likely failure to satisfy one or more of the Recognition Requirements may affect its objectives [#SRC:c6a75fa0-e9f4-459e-972a-a06f6236f8c6].

debug_context.source_text: In considering whether it would be appropriate to exercise its powers to issue directions under Rule 6.6.1 or Rule 6.7.2, the Regulator will have regard to all relevant information and factors including: (a) the Rules contained in MIR; (b) the results of its routine supervision of the Recognised Body concerned; (c) the extent to which the failure or likely failure to satisfy one or more of the Recognition Requirements may affect the objectives of the Regulator.
debug_context.target_text: The Regulator has the power to give a direction to a Recognised Body in matters relating to its Controllers if it considers that it is desirable to give the direction in order to advance one of more of its operational objectives.

question: What records must an Authorised Person keep about Client classification and agreements, and what other related documents are needed?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must keep records of Client classification and agreements as part of their Resolution Pack, according to specific rules [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. They also need to keep records of the procedures they followed, including documents showing how Clients are classified [#TGT:9c409857-238c-4ad8-b88b-6e770b674f27]. Additionally, any notices sent to Clients and proof of sending these notices must be recorded [#TGT:9c409857-238c-4ad8-b88b-6e770b674f27]. This ensures all necessary documentation is maintained for compliance.

debug_context.source_text: The following records must be included in the Resolution Pack of an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business: (a) Rules 2.7.1 and 3.7.1(d) (records of Client classification and Client agreements); (b) Rules 14.6.2 and 15.4.3 (master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments); (c) Rule 15.4.4 and Rule 15.4.5 (adequate records and Client's written permission re use of Client Investments); (d) Rules 14.7.1 and 14.7.4 (assessment of appropriateness of Third-Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party agent in respect of Client Money); and (e) Rule 15.5.1 and 15.6.1 (assessment of appropriateness of Third Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Investments); and (f) Rule 14.11.1 and 15.9.1 (most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments).
debug_context.target_text: In addition to any applicable rules under GEN relating to record keeping, and the remainder of these Rules, an Authorised Person must keep records of: (a) the procedures which it has followed under these Rules, including any documents which evidence the Client's classification; and (b) any notice sent to the Client pursuant to these Rules and evidence of despatch.

question: How much does it cost to list Digital Securities and to apply for Money Services permission?
expected_answer: An Applicant must pay different fees depending on their application type. To list Digital Securities on the Official List, the fee is US$3,000 [#SRC:e6bea365-9269-4a14-ac6b-2ccf805f85f9]. For applying to provide Money Services, the fee varies: $15,000 for Currency Exchange or Money Remittance, and $25,000 for Payment Services [#TGT:6ba8367f-82df-4c72-a188-980f7efc3b1b].

question: What should a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity include in its quarterly report about reserves and resources, and how recent must the data be?
expected_answer: A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must include a Summary of Reserves and Resources in its quarterly report at least once every 12 months, unless it is already part of the annual report [#SRC:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62]. The data in this Summary should be formatted as a table according to MKT Form 12-1 and must be current as of a date no earlier than one month before the disclosure [#TGT:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04]. This ensures the data is up-to-date and presented consistently.

debug_context.source_text: Quarterly Reports Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entities. A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must disclose a report for each quarter of its financial year containing the following information in respect of the Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity and all controlled entities, on a consolidated basis, if applicable: (1) details of the activities relating to Petroleum: (a) Exploration, or a statement that there have been no activities relating to Exploration; and (b) production and development, or a statement that there have been no activities relating to mining production and development; (2) a summary of any expenditure incurred relating to Petroleum: (a) Exploration activities; and (b) production and development; (3) the Petroleum Tenements held at the end of the quarter, their location and the percentage interest held, including the beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements; (4) the Petroleum Tenements, including beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements, acquired or disposed of during the quarter, and their location; (5) at least once every 12 months, the Summary of Reserves and Resources required by Rule 12.14.1 unless it is included in the Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entitys annual report; and (6) when the previous, and upcoming, disclosure required by (5) was, and is, to be disclosed.
debug_context.target_text: Subject to Rule 12.14.3, a Petroleum Reporting Entity must include in its Summary of Reserves and Resources a table in the form of MKT Form 12-1, as of a date no earlier than one month prior to the disclosure of the Summary of Reserves and Resources.

question: When might the Regulator change an Approved Person's role instead of taking it away, and how does this relate to their fitness for the job?
expected_answer: The Regulator might change an Approved Person's role if there are concerns about their performance that do not justify taking away their role completely. This can happen if the person hasn't shown enough skill or care in their job or if their behavior doesn't meet the expected standards [#SRC:61383442-b7af-4486-ab5c-610a613f73a2]. However, if the Regulator thinks the person isn't fit for the job at all, they can remove the Approval under section 45 [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554]. So, changing the role instead of removing it depends on how serious the issues are with the person's suitability.

debug_context.source_text: There are various circumstances that may arise where we may exercise our own initiative power to vary the Approval of an Approved Person, including where: (a) the Approved Person has not exercised the expected level of skill, care and diligence in carrying out the Controlled Function(s); (b) the conduct of the Approved Person is inconsistent with the requirements and standards expected of a person in their role; or (c) we have concerns about the Approved Persons ability or suitability to carry out the Controlled Function(s) as originally approved (but not such as to warrant the withdrawal of an Approved Persons status on the basis of fitness or propriety pursuant to section 46 of FSMR as set out in paragraphs 5.6.1 and 5.6.2).
debug_context.target_text: Withdrawal of Controlled Function Approval The Regulator may withdraw an Approval given under section â€Ž45 if the Regulator considers that the person is not a fit and proper person to perform the Controlled Function in question.

question: When a Recognised Investment Exchange operates a Multilateral Trading Facility using Virtual Assets, what compliance obligations must it fulfill under the Virtual Asset Framework and the Recognition Requirements?
expected_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange operating a Multilateral Trading Facility (MTF) using Virtual Assets must adhere to specific compliance obligations. Firstly, the Recognition Order must include a stipulation permitting the operation of an MTF with Virtual Assets [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb]. Once this stipulation is granted, the Recognised Investment Exchange is required to comply with the Virtual Asset Framework specifically for the operation of the MTF using Virtual Assets [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb]. Additionally, the Recognised Investment Exchange must ensure that the market it operates, whether an MTF or an Organised Trading Facility (OTF), complies with the broader Recognition Requirements [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d]. This dual compliance ensures that both the specific virtual asset operations and the overall market operations meet regulatory standards.

debug_context.source_text: MULTILATERAL TRADING FACILITIES AND VIRTUAL ASSETS Recognised Investment Exchanges Operating an MTF using Virtual Assets Pursuant to MIR Rule 3.4.1, a Recognised Investment Exchange may operate an MTF, provided that its Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to do so. MIR Rule 3.4.2 requires that where such a stipulation is granted to a Recognised Investment Exchange, the Recognised Investment Exchange must meet the requirements of the Virtual Asset Framework in relation to operation of an MTF (using Virtual Assets) while the remainder of its operations must be operated in compliance with the MIR Rules.
debug_context.target_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange operating an MTF or an OTF, must also operate a market that complies with the Recognition Requirements.

question: When can the Regulator publish a notice, and what happens if someone appeals the decision?
expected_answer: The Regulator can choose to publish a decision notice, final notice, or any other notice about its powers, except for warning notices [#TGT:de87bb07-107e-4bc3-a834-8f7457702841]. If someone appeals the decision to the Appeals Panel, the Regulator will publish the decision information, including the notice itself [#SRC:9ddabd85-89c9-44a4-a291-0388531f1314].

debug_context.source_text: Under section 252(3) of FSMR, we have the discretion to publish a decision notice, final notice or any other notice in relation to the exercise of our powers (other than a warning notice), and details about the matter to which the notice relates. Therefore, if a person exercises their right to refer a decision to the Appeals Panel, we will publish appropriate information about that decision, including the notice itself.
debug_context.target_text: A decision notice, final notice or any other notice in relation to the exercise of the Regulator's powers (other than a warning notice), and details about the matter to which such notice relates, may be published by the Regulator at its discretion.

question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator take action against a Fund Manager or its Agent promoting a Passported Fund in ADGM, and what actions may be taken if the activities are materially prejudicial despite measures by the Home Regulator?
expected_answer: The Regulator may take action against a Fund Manager, its Agent, or any other Licensed Person promoting a Passported Fund in ADGM if their activities continue to be materially prejudicial to the Unitholders situated in ADGM or to the financial stability or integrity of ADGM, despite any measures taken by the Home Regulator [#TGT:722d2090-eec8-4ae1-8d98-db9a10f13e55]. In such cases, the Regulator may prevent further promotion of the Passported Fund, de-register the fund from its Register of Passported Funds, or impose a penalty on the Fund Manager, its Agent, or any other Licensed Person, following consultation with the Home Regulator [#SRC:d4ba7643-bc71-443d-aab5-fac9738f8ae5].

debug_context.source_text: Subject to Rule 9.5.2, the Regulator may take any action that is necessary and appropriate to enable it to further its objectives, including, but not limited to: (a) preventing the Fund Manager, its Agent or any other Licensed Person from further Promotion of the Passported Fund in ADGM, including de-registering the relevant Passported Fund from its Register of Passported Funds; and (b) imposing a penalty on the Fund Manager, its Agent or any other Licensed Person, of such amount as it considers appropriate under applicable ADGM legislation, following consultation with the Home Regulator.
debug_context.target_text: If, despite the measures (if any) taken by a Home Regulator in relation to a Passported Fund, a Fund Manager's activities (or the activities of its Agent or any other Licensed Person that is Promoting the Passported Fund) in ADGM continue to be materially prejudicial to either: (a) the Unitholders of the Passported Fund who are situated in ADGM; or (b) the financial stability or the integrity of ADGM, the Regulator may request urgent discussions with the Home Regulator who has the supervision and enforcement responsibilities in respect of the Passported Fund.

question: When does an MTF or OTF need to show the FSRA its plans for using a Spot Commodity Settlement Facility, and what happens if a Recognised Clearing House can't settle a transaction?
expected_answer: An MTF or OTF needs to show the FSRA its plans for using a Spot Commodity Settlement Facility (SCSF) when it does not use a Recognised Clearing House (RCH) for settling Accepted Spot Commodities. The SCSF must meet certain rules, specifically MIR Rule 4.3.3, which treats the SCSF like an RCH for these purposes [#SRC:dd55d3d1-2eb7-4c91-ae7c-a494a1577f1c]. If a Recognised Clearing House cannot settle a specific transaction, it is not automatically seen as failing to meet its Recognition Requirement [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e].

debug_context.source_text: REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS - SPOT COMMODITY ACTIVITIES Spot Commodity Settlement Facilities (SCSFs) Pursuant to MIR Rule 3.8.3, however, and in the context of Accepted Spot Commodities, an MTF/OTF must provide the FSRA the satisfactory arrangements made when such MTF or OTF does not engage a RCH (for example, to use in this context, when it has engaged, or proposing to engage, an SCSF). To clarify, the FSRA will require that arrangements to use an SCSF for settlement purposes will require the SCSF to comply with the requirements of MIR Rule 4.3.3 (with the references to a RCH being read as references to an SCSF).
debug_context.target_text: A Recognised Clearing House will not be regarded as failing to comply with the Recognition Requirement merely because it is unable to arrange for a specific transaction to be settled.

question: What are the obligations of a Reporting Entity of a Listed Fund regarding the disclosure of preliminary annual financial results, and how do these obligations interact with Rule 10.1.3A(1) and Rule 10.1.3B?
expected_answer: A Reporting Entity of a Listed Fund is required to disclose a preliminary statement of annual financial results immediately following Board approval, unless compliance with Rule 10.1.3B is mandated [#TGT:23ed5ac2-6406-45d9-b480-d3ff6ebc4d21]. This disclosure must adhere to the requirements of Rule 10.1.3A(1) [#SRC:981f66c8-bfe8-4093-87a4-af05de4ed5e3]. The preliminary statement must be formatted as a table and include items necessary for a half-yearly report, consistent with the annual accounts' presentation [#TGT:23ed5ac2-6406-45d9-b480-d3ff6ebc4d21]. It must also indicate the auditor's involvement status and any potential qualifications or emphasis-of-matter wording for the auditor's report in the annual financial report [#TGT:23ed5ac2-6406-45d9-b480-d3ff6ebc4d21]. Additionally, any significant information necessary for assessing the results must be included [#TGT:23ed5ac2-6406-45d9-b480-d3ff6ebc4d21].

debug_context.source_text: Disclosure of Preliminary Results. A Reporting Entity of a Listed Fund must comply with the requirements of Rule 10.1.3A(1).
debug_context.target_text: A Reporting Entity must immediately Disclose a preliminary statement of annual financial results following Board approval, unless it is otherwise required to comply with Rule 10.1.3B. The preliminary statement of annual financial results must: (a) be presented in the form of a table and include the items required for a half-yearly report, consistent with the presentation to be adopted in the annual accounts for the financial year; (b) include the status of auditor involvement in the preparation of the preliminary statement of annual financial results; (c) include details of any likely qualification or emphasis-of-matter wording that may be required to be included in the auditorâ€™s report to be included in the annual financial report; and (d) include any significant additional information necessary for the purpose of assessing the results being announced.

question: If an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C, or 4 has Capital Resources below 120% of its Capital Requirement, what must they do and how should they inform the Regulator?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C, or 4 must notify the Regulator immediately if its Capital Resources fall below 120% of its Capital Requirement [#SRC:c08e86ed-69f1-4d9f-81bf-af5206de7e41]. question: What are the due diligence obligations of a PFP Operator before publishing a financing proposal, and how must these obligations be disclosed to PFP Clients on the Private Financing Platform?
expected_answer: A PFP Operator is required to conduct thorough due diligence on a PFP Prospect before publishing a financing proposal on a Private Financing Platform. This due diligence must include an assessment of the management's fitness and propriety, the financial soundness and regulatory status of the PFP Prospect, and the adequacy and clarity of the financing proposal itself [#SRC:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. Additionally, the PFP Operator must disclose the methodology and limitations of this due diligence to PFP Clients on the platform, ensuring transparency and compliance with Rule 18.4.1 [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f].

debug_context.source_text: Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect: (a) details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers; (b) background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and (c) the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operators knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.
debug_context.target_text: A PFP Operator must ensure that the following information, available to PFP Clients, is published on a Private Financing Platform it operates: (a) a statement identifying the risks involved in participating in financing proposals identified on the Private Financing Platform; (b) a statement confirming that the PFP Operator is not providing credit or investment advice to any PFP Client or PFP Prospect, and advising PFP Clients to seek independent advice prior to entering into any transaction; (c) the terms of operation of the Private Financing Platform, including the PFP Operatorâ€™s remuneration model; (d) the details of any potential conflicts of interest between the PFP Operator, PFP Clients and any PFP Prospect; (e) the details of the Eligible Custodian engaged by the PFP Operator, if so appointed; (f) the wind-down arrangements the PFP Operator has in place to ensure the orderly administration of transactions facilitated on the Private Financing Platform it operates in the event of its failure; (g) the details of any financing proposal published on the Private Financing Platform; (h) the criteria and methodology for accepting a PFP Prospectâ€™s financing proposal for publication on a Private Financing Platform; (i) the methodology of, and limitations to, the due diligence undertaken by the PFP Operator concerning each PFP Prospect identified on the Private Financing Platform, in accordance with Rule 18.4.1; (j) the governance and operational arrangements of any Body Corporate used as an intermediary between a PFP Client and any PFP Prospect; (k) the details of the exit facility, if any, that the PFP Operator offers upon the Private Financing Platform, in accordance with Rule 18.8; and (l) any other relevant information concerning the roles or obligations of the PFP Operator that a PFP Client should be aware of.

question: What steps must an Applicant take to apply for a listing, and when should they talk to the Regulator about the application date?
expected_answer: To apply for a listing, an Applicant must follow specific steps: submit the required documents in the final form as the Regulator prescribes, pay the fee at the time of submission, and provide any additional documents or information needed, including those in Rules 2.4.4 and 2.4.5 [#TGT:51448452-8fa0-4ada-97cb-b76691244d25]. Before submitting these documents, the Applicant should contact the Regulator to agree on the date when the application will be considered [#SRC:ee79fd3b-39df-41b9-adf4-6dde94de9527].

debug_context.source_text: Before submitting the documents referred to in Rule 2.4.1, an Applicant should contact the Regulator to agree the date on which the Regulator will consider the application.
debug_context.target_text: Listing application. An Applicant must apply to the Regulator by: (1) submitting in final form the relevant documents in such form as the Regulator shall prescribe; (2) paying the fee set out in the FEES Rulebook at the time of submission of the completed application form; (3) submitting all additional documents, explanations and information as may be required by the Regulator, including the documents specified in Rules 2.4.4 and 2.4.5; and (4) submitting verification of any information in such manner as the Regulator may specify.

question: When figuring out which capital instruments to include in Available Stable Funding, what rules should an Authorised Person follow, and how does this relate to AT1 Capital?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person should identify capital instruments for Available Stable Funding by checking if they meet the requirements under Rule 3.10.2, Rule 3.11.2, and Rule 3.12.2, while excluding Tier 2 capital instruments with less than one year of maturity [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1]. For AT1 Capital, the instruments must meet the criteria in Rule 3.11.3, and include related Share premium accounts [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b]. Thus, the Authorised Person must ensure the instruments for Available Stable Funding also align with AT1 Capital criteria [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b].

debug_context.source_text: Available Stable Funding (ASF). Subject to Rule A10.4.6, an Authorised Person must identify its capital instruments that are to be included in its Available Stable Funding by considering the capital elements that are meet the requirements for eligibility under: (a) Rule 3.10.2; (b) Rule 3.11.2; and (c) Rule 3.12.2, excluding all Tier 2 capital instruments with residual maturity of less than one year.
debug_context.target_text: AT1 Capital consists of the sum of the following capital elements: (a) capital instruments which meet the eligibility criteria laid down in Rule 3.11.3; and (b) the Share premium accounts related to the instruments referred to in (a).

question: When can an Authorised Person use a 0% risk weight for a CR Exposure with a guarantee from a multilateral development bank, and who can provide these guarantees?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person can use a 0% risk weight for a CR Exposure if it involves certain multilateral development banks like the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank, or the European Commission [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16]. The guarantee must be from entities such as central governments, central banks, specific MDBs mentioned in Rule 4.12.8, international organisations in Rule 4.12.9, public sector enterprises, banks and securities firms in the bank asset class, or any entity with a credit rating of Credit Quality Grade 3 or better [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d].

debug_context.source_text: An Authorised Person may recognise the effects of CRM of a guarantee only if it is provided by any of the following entities: (a) central government or central bank; (b) MDB referred to in Rule 4.12.8; (c) International Organisations referred to in Rule 4.12.9; (d) PSE; (e) banks and Securities firms which qualify for inclusion in bank asset class; or (f) any other entity that has an external credit assessment from a recognised credit rating agency that maps to a Credit Quality Grade 3 or better.
debug_context.target_text: Multilateral development bank (MDB) asset class. An Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank or the European Commission.

question: When does Behaviour count as market manipulation, and why is following Accepted Market Practices important?
expected_answer: Behaviour counts as market manipulation when it involves making trades or orders that aren't for legitimate reasons and don't follow Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market [#SRC:fc73bafc-769d-41e1-a518-11e082daed8b]. This Behaviour must either create or likely create a false or misleading impression about the supply, demand, or price of Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities, or set their price at an abnormal or artificial level [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f].

debug_context.source_text: Section 92(4) of the FSMR provides that market manipulation amounts to: Behaviour [consisting] of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which - (a) give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or (b) secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.
debug_context.target_text: The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) whichâ€” (a) give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or (b) secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.

question: What happens if a Payment Order for a Low Value Payment Instrument can't be changed after consent, and how does this relate to the usual need to tell users about refusals?
expected_answer: Once a Payment Order for a Low Value Payment Instrument is sent or consent is given, it can't be changed [#SRC:a0213781-cf1e-47ae-befc-8e10afd8e60d]. Usually, if a Payment Order is refused, the provider must inform the user quickly and, if possible, explain why and how to fix any errors [#TGT:7c2360b7-d85f-4ec3-97e2-e91cb6e4ae40]. This shows a situation where the usual need to inform users about refusals might not apply.

debug_context.source_text: In the case of a Payment Order relating to a Low Value Payment Instrument: (a) a Payment Service Provider is not required to notify the Payment Service User of the refusal of a Payment Order relating to such Low Value Payment Instrument and the reasons for such refusal in accordance with Rule 19.14.2(1) if the non-execution is apparent from the context; (b) the Payer may not revoke the Payment Order under Rule 19.14.3 after transmitting the Payment Order or giving its consent to execute the Payment Transaction to the Payee; (c) execution periods other than those provided by Rule 19.15.2 may apply.
debug_context.target_text: Refusal of Payment Orders. Where a Payment Service Provider refuses to execute a Payment Order or to initiate a Payment Transaction, it must notify the Payment Service User at the earliest opportunity in the agreed manner of the refusal, and, if possible, the reasons for such refusal, including, if applicable, the procedure for rectifying any factual errors that led to the refusal.

question: What specific records must an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business include in their Resolution Pack, and how does Rule 16.1 influence this requirement?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must include specific records in their Resolution Pack as mandated by Rule 16.1, which requires maintaining and retrieving documents specified in Rule 16.3.1 and Rule 16.4.1 [#SRC:9dc5d839-07b0-4c04-9b95-1b5733012807]. The Resolution Pack must contain records such as those related to Client classification and agreements, master lists of Client Accounts for Client Money and investments, and records of Client's written permission regarding the use of Client Investments [#TGT:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. Additionally, it should include assessments and acknowledgements concerning Third-Party Agents and the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Investments [#TGT:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5].

debug_context.source_text: An Authorised Person falling within Rule 16.1 must maintain at all times and be able to retrieve, in the manner described in this chapter, the documents and records specified in Rule 16.3.1 and Rule 16.4.1 (the "Resolution Pack").

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator impose a suspension following a Trading Halt, and what is the maximum duration for a Trading Halt under Rule 7.8.1?
expected_answer: The Regulator may impose a suspension in accordance with Rule 2.6 either upon completion of the duration of the Trading Halt established under Rule 7.8.2 or at any time during the Trading Halt established under Rule 7.8.1 [#SRC:dd30220a-9ed3-4f7f-98aa-99f1bd8dd3da]. A Trading Halt imposed pursuant to Rule 7.8.1 cannot exceed two Business Days or such shorter period as the Regulator agrees [#TGT:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db].

question: How must a Money Remitter determine its Capital Requirement, considering both the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum and the Variable Capital Requirement?
expected_answer: A Money Remitter must calculate its Capital Requirement by determining the highest value among several specified components. The calculation involves the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum as outlined in Section 3.7 and the Variable Capital Requirement. The Variable Capital Requirement is calculated as the sum of percentages applied to different tiers of monthly payment volume: 1.25% of the first $10 million, 0.5% of the next $90 million, 0.25% of the next $150 million, and 0.125% of any remaining volume [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304][#TGT:b1b3ae34-d42b-4c08-83fb-9ddac72f228c].

debug_context.source_text: Subject to Rule 3.6A.7, an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission enabling it to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services must calculate the Capital Requirement for each activity it undertakes as the highest of: (a) the applicable Base Capital Requirement as set out in Section 3.3; and (b) (i) where it undertakes currency exchange the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum as set out in Section 3.7; (ii) for a Money Remitter: (A) the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum as set out in Section 3.7; and (B) the Variable Capital Requirement calculated in accordance with Rule 3.6A.2; (iii) for a Payment Account Provider the Variable Capital Requirement calculated in accordance with Rule 3.6A.4; or (iv) for a Stored Value Provider the Variable Capital Requirement calculated in accordance with Rule 3.6A.6.
debug_context.target_text: Money Remitters. A Money Remitter must calculate its Variable Capital Requirement as the sum of the following: (a) 1.25% of the first $10 million of monthly payment volume; (b) 0.5% of the next $90 million of monthly payment volume; (c) 0.25% of the next $150 million of monthly payment volume; and (d) 0.125% of any remaining monthly payment volume.

question: How must an Authorised Person ensure compliance when communicating about a Specified Investment, considering the requirements for an Offer of Securities in ADGM?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must take reasonable steps to ensure that any communication related to a Specified Investment is clear, fair, and not misleading [#TGT:a8ef44c9-fb33-4526-bbf5-6c7986418bb7]. This requirement aligns with the broader obligations under COBS Rule 3.2.1, which also apply to communications about Offers of Securities in ADGM as set out in chapter 4 of MKT [#SRC:48bcaa58-c3a9-4d7f-8042-bfb462cf2949].

debug_context.source_text: COBS Rule 3.2.1 requires an Authorised Person to take reasonable steps to ensure that any communication to a Person in relation to a Specified Investment is clear, fair and not misleading. Similarly, chapter 4 of MKT sets out the requirements on a Person who makes or intends to make an Offer of Securities in ADGM. Without limiting any requirements under COBS or MKT, the Regulator has developed the ADGM Green Bond Designation and the ADGM Sustainability-Linked Bond Designation to indicate that an ADGM Issuer is issuing a debenture that it asserts is in accordance with Qualifying Green Debenture Principles or Qualifying Sustainability-Linked Debenture Principles.
debug_context.target_text: When communicating information to a Person in relation to a Specified Investment or Regulated Activity, an Authorised Person must take reasonable steps to ensure that the communication is clear, fair and not misleading.

question: When an Authorised Person calculates its Credit Risk Capital Requirement, what parts of the Rules should they follow?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must follow the Rules in both Part 3 and Chapter 4 when calculating its Credit Risk Capital Requirement (CRCOM). Part 3, including Rules 3.5.1 and 3.5.2, along with Appendix 4, outlines the overall Capital Requirement, of which CRCOM is a part [#SRC:c03600d2-2dac-495b-bba4-fe457d5e7166]. Chapter 4 specifies the applicable Rules that must be adhered to for CRCOM calculation [#TGT:8b8d4332-205d-4188-b48d-748ecc15479a]. Thus, both sections are necessary for proper compliance.

debug_context.source_text: The Credit Risk Capital Requirement (also referred to in these Rules as CRCOM) is a component of the calculation of the overall Capital Requirement of an Authorised Person, as provided in Rules 3.5.1 and 3.5.2. The Rules in this Part 3, supplemented by App4, govern the manner of calculation of the CRCOM.
debug_context.target_text: CRCOM. An Authorised Person must calculate its Credit Risk Capital Requirement in accordance with the applicable Rules in Chapter 4.

question: What are the obligations of a Relevant Person when conducting an assurance assessment of an eKYC System, and how do these obligations relate to the appointment of a service provider for CDD?
expected_answer: A Relevant Person is obligated to ensure that an eKYC System is both reliable and independent, which is essential for compliance with all applicable Rules of the Regulator [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4]. This assurance assessment must also consider guidance from the Regulator and other relevant authorities. When appointing a service provider for Customer Due Diligence (CDD), the Relevant Person must conduct an initial assurance assessment to evaluate the service provider's suitability and ensure that the service provider's obligations are clearly documented in a binding agreement [#TGT:1f815e39-1a9b-4f7d-af18-65b633fed752]. The linkage between these obligations is that both processes require a thorough evaluation to ensure compliance and reliability, with the additional requirement of formalizing the service provider's obligations in a legal document.

debug_context.source_text: When undertaking an assurance assessment of an eKYC System for the purpose of Rule 9.3.1A, a Relevant Person should seek to establish that the eKYC System is reliable and independent, and allows the Relevant Person to comply with all applicable Rules of the Regulator. In addition, a Relevant Person should consider applying guidance on assurance standards issued by the Regulator, competent U.A.E. authorities, FATF, and other relevant standard setting bodies.
debug_context.target_text: Prior to appointing a service provider to undertake CDD, a Relevant Person must undertake an initial assurance assessment to evaluate the suitability of the service provider and must ensure that the service provider's obligations are clearly documented in a binding agreement.

question: Under what circumstances might a Recognised Clearing House be considered compliant with the Recognition Requirement despite being unable to settle a specific transaction, and how should this relate to the satisfactory arrangements referenced in Rule 3.8.1?
expected_answer: A Recognised Clearing House will not be deemed non-compliant with the Recognition Requirement solely due to its inability to settle a specific transaction [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e]. However, the satisfactory arrangements required by Rule 3.8.1 should incorporate the requirements outlined in Rule 4.3.3, which may provide further context or conditions under which such compliance is assessed [#SRC:549c69d5-2c89-4747-8878-9ae4ce57346e].

question: When can an Authorised Person treat Exposures as collateralised, and what counts as eligible financial Collateral under the FCCA?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person can treat Exposures as collateralised if they meet the conditions in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.8, which are about Credit Risk Mitigation (CRM) [#SRC:558596ee-af40-4c07-8067-9c5c25eebaa5]. Eligible financial Collateral under the FCCA includes instruments listed in Rule 4.13.5, equity Securities traded on a regulated exchange, and Units in a Collective Investment Fund investing in such equity Securities [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85]. The Fund's Units must have a daily public price, and 90% of its property must be in the listed instruments and equity Securities [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85].

debug_context.source_text: An Authorised Person can only treat Exposures as collateralised provided the conditions of Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.8 (relating to CRM) are met. Item (d) also includes cash received under a CLN issued by the Authorised Person and loans and Deposits of a Counterparty to or with the Authorised Person which are subject to an on balance sheet Netting agreement recognised under Section 4.13 (CRM).
debug_context.target_text: For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises: (a) any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5; (b) any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and (c) any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where: (i) a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and (ii) at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: Must an Authorised Person apply the COBS Rules, specifically Rule 3.4 on Suitability and Rule 6.5 on Best Execution, to all transactions involving Virtual Assets, even if there are restrictions or exceptions elsewhere in COBS?
expected_answer: Yes, an Authorised Person must apply the COBS Rules, including Rule 3.4 on Suitability and Rule 6.5 on Best Execution, to all transactions involving Virtual Assets. This requirement holds irrespective of any restrictions or exceptions to these Rules elsewhere in COBS [#TGT:60f7507b-7582-4d9b-8e9c-1e5a8ceeaf5e]. The application of these Rules is specifically mandated for Authorised Persons conducting Regulated Activities related to Virtual Assets [#SRC:3483a783-5aa5-4a3d-8e88-9c26ba4bed8a].

debug_context.source_text: SPECIFIC FSRA GUIDANCE ON THE VIRTUAL ASSET FRAMEWORK Application of particular Rules in COBSFor the purposes of the Virtual Asset Framework and Authorised Persons, the Rules referenced in COBS Rule 17.1.4 apply to all transactions undertaken by an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets. The Rules referenced in COBS Rule 17.1.4 are as follows: a) COBS Rule 3.4 (Suitability); b) COBS Rule 6.5 (Best Execution); c) COBS Rule 6.7 (Aggregation and Allocation); d) COBS Rule 6.10 (Confirmation Notes); e) COBS Rule 6.11 (Periodic Statements); and f) COBS Chapter 12 (Key Information and Client Agreement)).
debug_context.target_text: The following COBS Rules should be read as applying to all Transactions undertaken by an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, irrespective of any restrictions on application or any exception to these Rules elsewhere in COBS - (a) Rule 3.4 (Suitability); (b) Rule 6.5 (Best Execution); (c) Rule 6.7 (Aggregation and Allocation); (d) Rule 6.10 (Confirmation Notes); (e) Rule 6.11 (Periodic Statements); and (f) Chapter 12 (Key Information and Client Agreement).

question: How should an Authorised Person determine the frequency and extent of stress testing for its securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, considering the requirements for periodic testing and future transaction capabilities?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must determine the frequency and extent of stress testing based on the materiality of its securitisation volumes and off balance sheet Exposures [#SRC:053ecf47-4501-4027-a994-9ada059b5e73]. This determination is essential to fulfil the requirements of Rule 4.14.5, which mandates periodic stress tests for securitisation activities [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa]. The stress tests must include an evaluation of the future ability to transact securitisation for credit risk mitigation (CRM) or liquidity purposes [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa].

An Authorised Person must conduct periodic stress tests in relation to its securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, including testing of future ability to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes.

question: What must an Issuer do when offering Securities to the Public in ADGM to make sure they don't mislead people?
expected_answer: When offering Securities to the Public in ADGM, an Issuer must publish a Prospectus as required by Section 61 of FSMR, which is part of the broader requirements under Sections 58 to 71 of FSMR and Chapter 4 of the Markets Rules (MKT) [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]. The Issuer must also ensure that the Prospectus is free from misleading or deceptive statements or omissions, as such conduct is prohibited [#TGT:2b95e76b-8303-4264-a66c-d6723adfa1c1].

question: What capital must an Authorised Person hold when dealing with Virtual Assets, and how should this capital be kept?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person dealing with Virtual Assets must hold regulatory capital similar to a Recognised Investment Exchange, which includes an amount equal to six months' operational expenses and possibly an extra buffer of up to six months' expenses, unless the Regulator decides otherwise [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96]. This capital must be held in fiat currency due to the specific risks associated with Virtual Assets [#SRC:9795daec-7cae-4276-a676-296830fc723d].

debug_context.source_text: REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS FOR AUTHORISED PERSONS ENGAGED IN REGULATED ACTIVITIES IN RELATION TO VIRTUAL ASSETS Capital Requirements Given the nature of, and the risks associated with Virtual Assets, COBS Rule 17.3 requires an Authorised Person to hold regulatory capital in a manner consistent with MIR Rule 3.2.1 (being the requirements that a Recognised Investment Exchange must meet). Pursuant to these Rules, regulatory capital held by an Authorised Person must be in fiat form.
debug_context.target_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange shall hold the following capital: (a) an amount equal to 6 months' operational expenses; plus (b) unless the Regulator directs otherwise, an additional buffer amount of up to a further 6 months' operational expenses.

question: When can a Mining Reporting Entity skip some details in a new forecast financial report if they already shared information before?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity can skip some details in a new forecast financial report if they have already shared information before, under specific conditions. The new report must mention the earlier report that followed Rule 11.9.2 [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]. It should also confirm that the important assumptions from the first report are still true and unchanged [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]. If the forecast is based only on Inferred Mineral Resources, a special statement must be included [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]. If it is partly based on an Exploration Target, another specific statement is needed [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]. This information can relate to the entity's Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves or important Mining Projects [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d].

debug_context.source_text: If a Mining Reporting Entity has made a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1, then any subsequent disclosure in relation to forecast financial information derived from a Production Target need not include the information in Rule 11.9.2 where the subsequent disclosure: (1) references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with Rule 11.9.2; (2) contains a statement confirming that all the material assumptions in the initial disclosure upon which the forecast financial information derived from a Production Target is based continue to apply and have not materially changed; (3) if the Production Target upon which the forecast financial information is derived is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed forecast financial information to the effect of the statement set out in Rule 11.8.3(5)(d); and (4) if the Production Target upon which the forecast financial information is derived is based in part upon an Exploration Target, includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed forecast financial information to the effect of the statement set out in Rule 11.8.3(7)(b).
debug_context.target_text: Forecast financial information derived from a Production Target may be disclosed in relation to either a Mining Reporting Entityâ€™s: (1) Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings; or (2) material Mining Project(s).

question: Under what circumstances must a Payment Service Provider refund an unauthorised Payment Transaction and restore the Payment Account, considering the failure to provide information as per Section 19.5?
expected_answer: A Payment Service Provider is obligated to refund an unauthorised Payment Transaction and restore the Payment Account to its original state if the transaction was not authorised according to Rule 19.10.1 [#SRC:49dd4b51-276a-406c-ab4c-17a9797a7a7a]. This obligation persists even if the Payment Service User did not notify the Payment Service Provider within the time period specified in Rule 19.17.1, provided the Payment Service Provider failed to supply or make available the necessary information about the Payment Transaction as required by Section 19.5 [#TGT:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4].

debug_context.source_text: Subject to Rules 19.17.1, 19.17.2 and 19.18.1, where an executed Payment Transaction was not authorised in accordance with Rule 19.10.1, the Payment Service Provider must: (a) refund the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction to the Payer; and (b) where applicable, restore the debited Payment Account to the state it would have been in had the unauthorised Payment Transaction not taken place.
debug_context.target_text: Where the Payment Service Provider has failed to provide or make available information concerning the Payment Transaction in accordance with Section 19.5, the Payment Service User is entitled to redress under the Rules in this Chapter notwithstanding that the Payment Service User has failed to notify the Payment Service Provider within the time period stated in Rule 19.17.1.

question: How is an order classified as large in scale compared to normal market size for Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, and what are the minimum size requirements based on average daily turnover?
expected_answer: An order is classified as large in scale compared to normal market size if it meets or exceeds the minimum size specified in Rule 3.5.11 [#SRC:12e55ccd-cd6e-4509-aaf7-b0985942d627]. The classification of Financial Instruments is determined by their average daily turnover, as outlined in Rule 3.5.12 [#SRC:12e55ccd-cd6e-4509-aaf7-b0985942d627]. The minimum size of an order qualifying as large in scale varies based on the average daily turnover (ADT) of the instrument: for ADT less than or equal to USD 500,000, the minimum size is USD 50,000; for ADT between USD 500,000 and USD 1,000,000, it is USD 100,000; for ADT between USD 1,000,000 and USD 25,000,000, it is USD 250,000; for ADT between USD 25,000,000 and USD 50,000,000, it is USD 400,000; and for ADT greater than USD 50,000,000, the minimum size is USD 500,000 [#TGT:4d8f4efe-e1c0-4b4a-aafd-32081fee4d4b].

debug_context.source_text: Waivers in relation to transactions which are large in scale For the purpose of Rule 3.5.7(c), an order shall be considered to be large in scale compared with normal market size if it is equal to or larger than the minimum size of order specified in Rule 3.5.11. For the purposes of determining whether an order is large in scale compared to normal market size, all Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange market shall be classified in accordance with their average daily turnover, in accordance with Rule 3.5.12.

question: How must a Mining Reporting Entity ensure compliance when making disclosures that include statements about Exploration Targets or Ore Reserves, and what specific format considerations should be taken into account?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must prepare disclosures that include statements about Exploration Targets or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard and the relevant chapter requirements [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d]. Additionally, Issuers and Mining Reporting Entities should ensure consistency in their disclosures by adhering to the table format for Ore Reserves and Mineral Resources as specified in MKT Form-11-1 [#SRC:96612327-1f00-4faf-abc6-2c914cc73738].

debug_context.source_text: Rule 11.2.1 applies to all disclosures made or required to be made under the Rules which include a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets, including within a Prospectus, Exempt Offer document, bidders and targets statements, annual reports, financial statements, technical papers, presentations, and website content and disclosures. In order to ensure consistency of its disclosures, Issuers and Mining Reporting Entities should be mindful of the table format for disclosure of Ore Reserves and Mineral Resources set out in MKT Form-11-1.

A disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity that includes a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets must be prepared in accordance with: (1) a Mining Reporting Standard; and (2) this chapter.

question: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity makes a disclosure of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, or Petroleum Reserves, what are the requirements regarding the involvement and identification of the Competent Person(s), and how should subsequent disclosures be handled?
expected_answer: A Petroleum Reporting Entity must ensure that any disclosure of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, or Petroleum Reserves is based on information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s) [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79]. The disclosure must also state whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party, and if not, the name of the Competent Personâ€™s employer, as well as the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79]. Additionally, the initial disclosure must have the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) regarding the form and context of the information presented [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e]. For subsequent disclosures, the Petroleum Reporting Entity must reference the earlier disclosure and confirm that no new information materially affects the previous estimates, and that all assumptions and technical parameters remain unchanged [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e].

debug_context.source_text: Competent Persons . The statement referred to in Rule 12.15.2: (1) must only be disclosed with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which the estimated Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Prospective Resources, as the case may be, and the supporting information is presented in the disclosure; and (2) only applies the first time a Petroleum Reporting Entity discloses original or updated estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves where: (a) any subsequent disclosure that refers to the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves references the earlier disclosure containing the statements and consent referred to in Rules 12.15.2 and 12.15.3(1); and (b) the Petroleum Reporting Entity confirms in the subsequent disclosure that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure, and that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the estimates in the earlier disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed.
debug_context.target_text: Competent Persons . A disclosure by a Petroleum Reporting Entity containing Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves must state: (1) that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s); (2) whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Personâ€™s employer; and (3) the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: When an Authorised Person applies for a Financial Services Permission to operate a Multilateral Trading Facility involving Virtual Assets, what considerations must the Regulator take into account, and how should references to Investment be interpreted?
expected_answer: When an Authorised Person applies for a Financial Services Permission to operate a Multilateral Trading Facility involving Virtual Assets, the Regulator must consider several factors. These include whether the establishment of the facility is in the interests of the Financial Services and Markets industry, whether it will enhance price discovery or liquidity in an Investment, and whether there is a risk of market fragmentation or inefficiency in price discovery [#TGT:66edbeb0-e20b-498a-8b25-cfd2a59dae31]. Additionally, for an Authorised Person operating such a facility, all references to Investment must be interpreted as references to Virtual Assets [#SRC:726a7101-d094-4454-93b6-5e5561582705].

debug_context.source_text: GEN Rule 5.2.14 shall apply to an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, and all references to Investment shall be read as references to Virtual Asset.
debug_context.target_text: In assessing an application for a Financial Services Permission authorising the applicant to Operate a Multilateral Trading Facility or an Organised Trading Facility, the Regulator will have regard to, but is not limited to, considering the following matters: (1) whether the establishment of a Multilateral Trading Facility or Organised Trading Facility is, or is likely to be, in the interests of the Financial Services and Markets industry; (2) whether the Multilateral Trading Facility or Organised Trading Facility will or is likely to lead to more efficient price discovery of, or deepen liquidity in, an Investment; and (3) whether there is any risk of market fragmentation, loss of liquidity or inefficiency in price discovery as a result of the proposed Multilateral Trading Facility or Organised Trading Facility operation.

question: When does a FinTech Participant have to stop its activities in the RegLab, and what role does the Regulator play in changing or cancelling their permission?
expected_answer: A FinTech Participant must stop its activities in the RegLab if it cannot meet the required criteria within two years [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7]. This must happen when their Financial Services Permission (FSP) expires or if the Regulator decides to change or cancel the FSP [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7]. The Regulator can take the initiative to vary or cancel the permission, which affects when and how the FinTech Participant must stop its activities [#TGT:445d41e7-27aa-41c1-84e4-194553261f8a].

debug_context.source_text: Two-year validity period. If the FinTech Participant is unable to satisfy the above criteria, it will be required to cease carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab. The deadline for ceasing the Regulated Activity will be upon the expiry of its RegLab FSP, or at such time as the Regulator varies or cancels the FSP in accordance with section 33 of the FSMR. Please refer to section 8 below for more details.
debug_context.target_text: Variation and cancellation of a Financial Services Permission. Variation or cancellation on initiative of the Regulator

question: What must a PFP Operator check about a PFP Prospect before sharing their financing proposal, and what must they tell PFP Clients about this process?
expected_answer: Before sharing a financing proposal, a PFP Operator must check the PFP Prospect's management background, financial health, and the clarity of the proposal itself [#SRC:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. They must also inform PFP Clients about how they check these details and any limits to their checks, ensuring clients understand the process [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f].

debug_context.source_text: Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect: (a) details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers; (b) background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and (c) the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operators knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.
debug_context.target_text: A PFP Operator must ensure that the following information, available to PFP Clients, is published on a Private Financing Platform it operates: (a) a statement identifying the risks involved in participating in financing proposals identified on the Private Financing Platform; (b) a statement confirming that the PFP Operator is not providing credit or investment advice to any PFP Client or PFP Prospect, and advising PFP Clients to seek independent advice prior to entering into any transaction; (c) the terms of operation of the Private Financing Platform, including the PFP Operatorâ€™s remuneration model; (d) the details of any potential conflicts of interest between the PFP Operator, PFP Clients and any PFP Prospect; (e) the details of the Eligible Custodian engaged by the PFP Operator, if so appointed; (f) the wind-down arrangements the PFP Operator has in place to ensure the orderly administration of transactions facilitated on the Private Financing Platform it operates in the event of its failure; (g) the details of any financing proposal published on the Private Financing Platform; (h) the criteria and methodology for accepting a PFP Prospectâ€™s financing proposal for publication on a Private Financing Platform; (i) the methodology of, and limitations to, the due diligence undertaken by the PFP Operator concerning each PFP Prospect identified on the Private Financing Platform, in accordance with Rule 18.4.1; (j) the governance and operational arrangements of any Body Corporate used as an intermediary between a PFP Client and any PFP Prospect; (k) the details of the exit facility, if any, that the PFP Operator offers upon the Private Financing Platform, in accordance with Rule 18.8; and (l) any other relevant information concerning the roles or obligations of the PFP Operator that a PFP Client should be aware of.

question: When can the Regulator stop an auditor or actuary from working with certain financial groups, and what factors do they look at?
expected_answer: The Regulator can disqualify an auditor or actuary if they have broken the rules [#TGT:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e]. They will look at how serious the rule-breaking is, including if it could hurt customers, harm the ADGM's reputation, or lead to financial crime [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22].

debug_context.source_text: In deciding whether to exercise our power to disqualify an auditor or actuary under section 233(3) of FSMR, and what the scope of any disqualification will be, we will take into account all the circumstances of the case, including: (a) the nature and seriousness of any contravention of FSMR or Rules and the effect of that contravention; (b) whether any contravention of FSMR or Rules, or any failure to disclose information to us, has resulted in or is likely to result in: (i) loss to customers; (ii) damage to the reputation of the ADGM; or (iii) an increased risk that a firm, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity may be used for the purposes of financial crime; (c) any action taken by the auditor or actuary to remedy the contravention; (d) any disciplinary action taken (or to be taken) against the auditor or actuary by a relevant professional body, and whether that action adequately addresses the particular contravention; and (e) the previous compliance record of the auditor or actuary concerned, and whether the relevant regulatory body or professional body has imposed any previous disciplinary sanctions that may be relevant.
debug_context.target_text: If the Regulator considers that an auditor or actuary has committed a contravention of these Regulations, it may disqualify the auditor or actuary from being the auditor of, or (as the case may be), from acting as an actuary for, any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity or any particular class thereof.

question: When can an Authorised Person recognise CRM effects from a Credit Derivative by a multilateral development bank, and what risk weight is used for exposures to some international bodies?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person can recognise CRM effects from a Credit Derivative if it is provided by a multilateral development bank mentioned in specific rules [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b]. For exposures to international bodies like the Bank for International Settlements and the International Monetary Fund, a 0% risk weight must be applied [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16]. This shows that recognition of CRM effects depends on rule inclusion, while a specific risk weight applies to certain international exposures.

debug_context.source_text: An Authorised Person may recognise the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative only if it is provided by any of the following entities: (a) central government or central bank; (b) MDB referred to in Rules 4.12.7 to 4.12.9; (c) International Organisations referred to in Rule 4.12.9; (d) PSE; (e) banks and Securities firms which qualify for inclusion in bank asset class; or (f) any other entity that has an external credit assessment from a recognised credit rating agency that maps to a Credit Quality Grade 3 or better.
debug_context.target_text: Multilateral development bank (MDB) asset class. An Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank or the European Commission.

question: What obligations does a Third Party Provider have regarding the provision of information to a Customer upon request during the term of the Governing Contract, and how does this relate to the information required to be included in the Governing Contract itself?
expected_answer: A Third Party Provider is obligated to provide the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 and any other terms of the Governing Contract if the Customer requests it at any time during the term of the Governing Contract [#SRC:5d8a8993-1e40-440d-b801-ac0dadf9f0de]. The Governing Contract must include comprehensive details about the Third Party Provider, the Third Party Services, charges, communication, safeguards, changes to the contract, and redress mechanisms [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. This ensures that the Customer has access to all necessary information both proactively within the contract and reactively upon request.

debug_context.source_text: If the Customer so requests at any time during the term of the Governing Contract, the Third Party Provider must provide the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 as well as any other terms of the Governing Contract.
debug_context.target_text: Unless otherwise agreed in writing between a Third Party Provider and their Customer, the Governing Contract between the Third Party Provider and their Customers must contain the following information â€“ (a) about the Third Party Provider: (i) the name of the Third Party Provider; (ii) the address and contact details of the Third Party Providerâ€™s office in ADGM; (iii) the name of the Regulator of the Third Party Provider, and details of the Third Party Providerâ€™s Financial Service Permission; (b) about the Third Party Services: (i) a description of the main characteristics of the Third Party Services to be provided; (ii) the information or unique identifier that must be provided by the Customer in order for a Third Party Transaction to occur; (iii) the form and procedure for giving consent to a Third Party Transaction; (iv) the time of receipt of a Third Party Transaction; (v) the maximum time taken for the Third Party Services to be provided; and (vi) any limits for the use of the Third Party Services; (c) about charges and exchange rates: (i) details of all charges payable by the Customer to the Third Party Provider, including those connected to information which is provided or made available and, where applicable, a breakdown of the amounts of all charges; (ii) where relevant, details of the exchange rates to be applied or, if Reference Exchange Rates are to be used, the method of calculating the relevant date for determining such Reference Exchange Rates; (iii) where relevant and if agreed, the application of changes in Reference Exchange Rates and information requirements relating to any such changes; (d) about communication: (i) the means of communication agreed between the parties for the transmission of information or notifications including, where relevant, any technical requirements for the Customerâ€™s equipment and software for receipt of the information or notifications; (ii) the manner in which and frequency with which information under this Chapter is to be provided or made available; (iii) what information relating to the Customer will be transferred to the Customerâ€™s Financial Institution as part of a Third Party Transaction; (iv) the Customerâ€™s right to receive the revised terms of the Governing Contract and any other information in accordance with Rule 20.2.5; (e) about safeguards and corrective measures: (i) how and within what period of time the Customer must notify the Third Party Provider of any unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction; (ii) the secure procedure by which the Third Party Provider will contact the Customer in the event of suspected or actual fraud or security threats; (iii) where relevant, the conditions under which the Third Party Provider proposes to reserve the right to stop or prevent a Third Party Transaction from being executed; (iv) the Customerâ€™s liability under Rule 20.12.6 including details of any limits on such liability; (v) the Third Party Providerâ€™s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions under Rule 20.12.5; (vi) the conditions for the payment of any refund to the Customer under this Chapter (f) about changes to and termination of the contractual arrangement: (i) where relevant, the proposed terms under which the Customer will be deemed to have accepted changes to the Governing Contract in accordance with Rule 20.2.6, unless they notify the Third Party Provider that they do not accept such changes before the proposed date of their entry into force; (ii) the duration of the Governing Contract; (iii) where relevant, the right of the Customer to terminate the Governing Contract and any agreements relating to termination in accordance with Rule 20.2.6. (g) about redress: (i) any contractual clauses on the law applicable to the Governing Contract and the competent courts; and (ii) the availability of any alternative dispute resolution procedures, if applicable, for the Customer and the methods for having access to them.

question: What steps does the Regulator take if it doesn't approve something, and how is this linked to making directions or refusing a Recognition Order?
expected_answer: If the Regulator does not approve something, it follows a specific procedure as per Rule 6.9.6 [#SRC:fabe80d0-c823-4b53-bd71-de06ee4afccf]. This is linked to the steps the Regulator takes when making directions or refusing a Recognition Order, except in certain cases like revocation with consent or when skipping steps is necessary [#TGT:8f0e941a-957c-499b-952d-fa26d94c0efd]. The Regulator must send a written notice explaining the reasons and invite comments within a set time [#TGT:8f0e941a-957c-499b-952d-fa26d94c0efd]. It considers the comments and informs the Recognised Body or Applicant of its final decision in writing [#TGT:8f0e941a-957c-499b-952d-fa26d94c0efd].

debug_context.source_text: The Regulator will follow the procedure set out in Rule 6.9.6 if it does not give its approval.
debug_context.target_text: The procedures that the Regulator will follow in exercising its powers to make directions or refuse to make a Recognition Order (except in the case of a revocation of a Recognition Order, the Recognised Body concerned has given its consent or, in case where the Regulator proposes to make a direction, it considers it is reasonably necessary not to follow, or to cut short, the procedure) are: /Table Start The Regulator will: Guidance 1. give written notice to the Recognised Body (or Applicant); The notice will state why the Regulator intends to take the action it proposes to take, and include an invitation to make representations, and the period within which representations should be made (unless subsequently extended by the Regulator). 2. receive representations from the Recognised Body or Applicant concerned; The Regulator will not usually consider oral representations without first receiving written representations from the Recognised Body or Applicant. It will normally only hear oral representations from the Recognised Body or Applicant on request. 3. write promptly to the Recognised Body or Applicant who requests the opportunity to make oral representations if it decides not to hear that Person's representations; The Regulator will indicate why it will not hear oral representations and the Regulator will allow the Recognised Body or Applicant further time to respond. 4. have regard to representations made; 5. (when it has reached its decision) notify the Recognised Body or Applicant concerned in writing. /Table End

question: How should an MTF Operator interpret references to Financial Instruments in the context of MIR rules when complying with transaction recording requirements?
expected_answer: An MTF Operator, when complying with transaction recording requirements under MIR 2.7.1 and 2.7.2, must interpret references to Financial Instruments as references to Accepted Spot Commodities. This interpretation aligns with the guidance provided in COBS, Chapter 8, where references to Financial Instruments are to be read as Accepted Spot Commodities for the purposes of Rules 22.7.1 and 22.7.2 [#SRC:27f8e3fb-1055-4605-bb11-0b75eba743c2]. Additionally, the MTF Operator must adhere to the requirements applicable to a Recognised Body or Recognised Investment Exchange as set out in the MIR rulebook, ensuring that references to these entities are read as if they were references to the MTF Operator [#TGT:180edda8-db12-4969-97d5-182435bdf094].

debug_context.source_text: For the purposes of Rules 22.7.1 and 22.7.2, the following references in COBS, Chapter 8 should be read as follows: (a) references to Investment or Investments shall be read as references to Spot Commodity or Spot Commodities, and (b) references to Financial Instrument or Financial Instruments (including those in MIR as incorporated by virtue of COBS Rule 8.2.1) shall be read as references to Accepted Spot Commodity or Accepted Spot Commodities as applicable.
debug_context.target_text: In addition to the general requirements applicable to Authorised Persons in COBS, GEN and elsewhere in the Rules, an Authorised Person carrying on the Regulated Activity of Operating an MTF (an "MTF Operator") or an Authorised Person carrying on the Regulated Activity of Operating an OTF (an â€œOTF Operatorâ€) must comply with the following requirements applicable to a Recognised Body or Recognised Investment Exchange set out in the MIR rulebook, reading references to Recognised Bodies or Recognised Investment Exchanges in the relevant rules as if they were references to the MTF Operator or OTF Operator: (a) MIR 2.6 (Operational systems and controls); (b) MIR 2.7.1 and 2.7.2 (Transaction recording); (c) MIR 2.8 (Membership criteria and access); (d) MIR 2.9 (Financial crime and market abuse); (e) MIR 2.11 (Rules and consultation); (f) MIR 3.3 (Fair and orderly trading); (g) MIR 3.5 (Pre-trade transparency obligations); (h) MIR 3.6 (Post-trade transparency obligations); (i) MIR 3.7 (Public disclosure); (j) MIR 3.8 (Settlement and Clearing Services); (k) MIR 3.10 (Default Rules); and (l) MIR 3.11 (Use of Price Reporting Agencies).
