question: When does an Authorised Person have to give up their Financial Services Permission if they want to run a Recognised Investment Exchange, and what does the Recognition Order need to say for them to operate an MTF or OTF?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must give up their Financial Services Permission when they get a Recognition Order to run a Recognised Investment Exchange (RIE) [#SRC:d27a9a5d-f443-4ca1-a549-8316b911bfe7]. The Recognition Order needs to say that the RIE can operate an MTF or OTF [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388]. If it says this, the specific rules for MTFs and OTFs in COBS will apply, but only to that part of their operations [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388].

debug_context.source_text: REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS - SPOT COMMODITY ACTIVITIES RIEs operating an MTF or OTF using Accepted Spot Commodities Authorised Persons that are operating an MTF or OTF wishing to also operate a RIE will be required to relinquish their FSP upon obtaining a Recognition Order (to operate the RIE). If licensed by the FSRA to carry out both Regulated Activities (e.g., operating an MTF and operating an RIE), the Recognition Order will include a stipulation to that effect pursuant to MIR Rule 3.4.1.
debug_context.target_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange may carry on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF or OTF provided that its Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to do so. If it does include such a stipulation, the specific rules on MTFs and OTFs in COBS will apply to that function, but that function only.

question: When can a Recognised Investment Exchange delay some rules for big trades, and what must they do about reporting trades in real-time?
expected_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange can delay the requirements of Rule 3.6.1 for large volume or specific types of trades if the deferral terms are shared with Members, users, and investors [#SRC:7f823646-b062-4581-a37a-a39040c4edad]. Even with such delays, they must still report the price, volume, and time of trades to the public and the Regulator as soon as possible, considering what is technically and financially reasonable [#TGT:1a356c1e-9ff4-4ac4-a46d-1f2fd06ac0a6].

debug_context.source_text: Deferrals. The Regulator may permit the requirements of Rule 3.6.1 to be deferred in respect of large volume or for certain types of trades, as specified in Rule 3.6.8, in which case the Recognised Investment Exchange must ensure that the existence of and the terms of the deferral are disclosed to Members and users of their facilities, and to investors.
debug_context.target_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange must make arrangements for the price, volume and time of transactions executed in Financial Instruments to be made available to the public and the Regulator as close to real-time as technically possible assuming a reasonable level of efficiency and of expenditure on systems on the part of the Recognised Investment Exchange, provided that: (a) information relating to a portfolio trade shall be made available with respect to each constituent transaction as close to real time as possible, having regard to the need to allocate prices to particular Financial Instruments; and (b) post-trade information referring to transactions taking place on a Recognised Investment Exchange but outside its normal trading hours shall be made public before the opening of the next trading day of the Recognised Investment Exchange.

question: What are the annual supervision fee requirements for an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, and how do these requirements differ when the activity involves operating a Multilateral Trading Facility?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets is required to pay an annual supervision fee of $15,000 for each Regulated Activity undertaken [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8]. However, if the Regulated Activity involves operating a Multilateral Trading Facility (MTF) in relation to Virtual Assets, the fee increases to $60,000 [#SRC:9a65518c-820e-4e90-abba-4a05d7c482c0]. This fee structure is applicable in addition to any other supervision fees due for each Regulated Activity the Authorised Person undertakes [#TGT:febdfdb0-1bc0-41ad-a131-4be1812571f8].

debug_context.source_text: FEES Authorisation and supervision fees Pursuant to FEES Rule 3.17.2, annual supervision fees for an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, payable in accordance with paragraph 1 of the FEES Rulebook, are set as follows: a) $15,000; or b) $60,000 if the Applicant is seeking to operate an MTF (in relation to Virtual Assets).
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets must pay to the Regulator, in addition to the supervision fees due in respect of each Regulated Activity which the Authorised Person undertakes, an annual supervision fee of: (a) $15,000 for each Regulated Activity; or (b) $60,000 if the Regulated Activity is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility without any additional Regulated Activity.

question: When does using a Recognised Clearing House or Remote Clearing House meet Rule 3.8.1, and what must a Recognised Investment Exchange do to make sure transactions are settled on time?
expected_answer: Using a Recognised Clearing House or Remote Clearing House is enough to meet Rule 3.8.1 [#SRC:9217cc24-dbcc-43e5-8884-f398ee26b820]. A Recognised Investment Exchange must make sure there are good arrangements for settling the rights and liabilities of transactions on time. This includes clearing and settling these through performance, compromise, or other methods [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616].

debug_context.source_text: The engagement of a Recognised Clearing House or Remote Clearing House will be deemed sufficient to satisfy Rule 3.8.1.
debug_context.target_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange, when engaging a Clearing Service, must ensure that satisfactory arrangements are made for securing the timely discharge (whether by performance, compromise or otherwise), Clearing and settlement of the rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions effected on the Recognised Investment Exchange (being rights and liabilities in relation to those transactions).

question: What should a Reporting Entity do if the Listing Authority can't reach its contact points, and how does this connect to preparing disclosures?
expected_answer: If the Listing Authority cannot reach the Reporting Entity's contact points, or if they lack the authority to handle disclosure issues, the Listing Authority might suspend the Listed Entity's Securities until the issue is resolved [#SRC:8fbe10b4-f49e-4b93-b470-a3c663f2ab94]. To avoid such situations, the Reporting Entity should have a template letter ready for requesting a Trading Halt and ensure its Officers have the authority to make necessary disclosures [#TGT:40f90ce3-56d4-440a-abf9-2ab4b8249d8e].

debug_context.source_text: DISCLOSURES SYSTEMS, CONTROLS & CONTENT Other Reporting Entity steps to assist with compliance with Rule 7.2.1 The issue set out in paragraph 148h) above is most important, as the need to resolve a continuous disclosure matter may be extremely sensitive, and time critical. In circumstances where the Listing Authority is not able to contact the Reporting Entity (being the Reporting Entitys designated contact points with the Listing Authority), or the Reporting Entitys designated contacts do not have the organisational knowledge or authority to address the matter promptly, the Listing Authority may Suspend the Listed Entitys Securities until the matter is properly resolved.
debug_context.target_text: DISCLOSURES â€“ SYSTEMS, CONTROLS & CONTENT Other Reporting Entity steps to assist with compliance with Rule 7.2.1 Steps or actions that a Reporting Entity can take to help manage its disclosure obligations under Rule 7.2.1 include: a) To allow a Reporting Entity to urgently request a Trading Halt without delay, having a template letter ready for use at all times requesting the Listing Authority to grant a Trading Halt. b) Anticipating what might happen if the Inside Information leaks about a confidential transaction being negotiated, and have a template Disclosure ready that can be finalised and Disclosed straight away. c) Where it has advance notice of an event that is likely to require Disclosure under Rule 7.2.1, preparing a draft Disclosure ahead of time, allowing it to be Disclosed immediately. d) Where the event that gives rise to the need to make a Disclosure is within its control, being sensitive to the RIEâ€™s market (upon which the Listed Entityâ€™s Securities are admitted to trading) trading hours and, where possible, looking to ensure the event happens and the Disclosure is made before trading commences or after trading closes (so as to avoid any disruption to the normal course of trading of the Listed Entityâ€™s Securities of theâ€™RIE's market). e) Ensuring that it, and its relevant Officers responsible for communication with the Listing Authority, has the: (i) organisational knowledge to have relevant and meaningful discussions on Rule matters; and (ii) authority to request a Trading Halt or Suspension and make a Disclosure, if that is what is required under the Rules. f) Ensuring that it has appropriate arrangements in place to control, or deny, access to Inside Information (pursuant to Rules 7.2.7 to 7.2.9). The Listing Authority encourages efforts to keep the numbers of these â€˜insidersâ€™ to a minimum. g) Ensuring that it has in place arrangements for maintaining the confidentiality of Inside Information before Disclosure. These should include adequate training for Employees in the handling, distribution and announcement of Inside Information as appropriate. Reporting Entities should, for example, guard against the risk of Inside Information being leaked to the market through selective disclosure or otherwise. h) Ensuring that it is readily contactable by the Listing Authority by phone, and available to discuss any pressing Disclosure issues that arise, during the normal trading hours (on the RIE for which the Listed Entityâ€™s Securities are admitted to trading) and for at least one hour either side of the RIEâ€™s normal trading hours each Business Day.

question: When does the Regulator need to talk to the Recognised Body before making a direction under Rule 6.5.4 or Rule 6.5.6, and what must they consider to be sure about the direction?
expected_answer: The Regulator must talk to the Recognised Body before making a direction under both Rule 6.5.4 and Rule 6.5.6. For Rule 6.5.4, they need to be sure that not acting would risk investors or market players, that the direction is needed for public financial stability, or that it helps with using a power under chapter 16 of COBS or Rule 6.5.7(c) [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a]. For Rule 6.5.6, they must see if acting would be too soon or not good for investors or market players, that the direction is needed for public financial stability, or that it helps with using a power under chapter 16 of COBS or a specific power under that Part [#TGT:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3].

debug_context.source_text: Before giving such a direction under Rule 6.5.4, the Regulator shall consult the Recognised Body in question, and the Regulator shall not give a direction unless the Regulator is satisfied, in the light of that consultation that: (a) failure to take action would involve undue risk to investors or other participants in the market; (b) the direction is necessary having regard to the public interest in the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or (c) the direction is necessary to facilitate a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS or in connection with a particular exercise of a power under that chapter, or Rule 6.5.7(c).
debug_context.target_text: Before giving a direction under Rule 6.5.6, the Regulator shall consult the Recognised Body in question, and the Regulator shall not give a direction unless the Regulator is satisfied, in the light of that consultation that: (a) the taking of action would be premature or otherwise undesirable in the interests of investors or other participants in the market; (b) the direction is necessary having regard to the public interest in the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or (c) the direction is necessary to facilitate a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS or in connection with a particular exercise of a power under that Part.

question: How must an Authorised Person calculate E* for pre-settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs when eligible financial Collateral is taken and the transaction is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must calculate E* for pre-settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs by applying the FCCA when eligible financial Collateral is taken and the transaction is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de]. The calculation of E* involves determining the appropriate haircuts, which can be done using either standard supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts [#TGT:19b5846d-b958-4e12-a8d2-ffe1b2dd7ed8]. Once E* is calculated, it must be substituted for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount under Section 4.8 [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de].

debug_context.source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT that is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4, and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for that CR Exposure under Section 4.8.
debug_context.target_text: Calculation of E* for collateralised transactions other than OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions. An Authorised Person must calculate the appropriate haircuts to be applied using one of the following methods: (a) standard supervisory haircuts; or (b) own estimate haircuts.

question: When can a Payment Service User ask for the terms of the Framework Contract, and what must be included in the contract?
expected_answer: A Payment Service User can request the terms of the Framework Contract at any time during its term, and the Payment Service Provider must provide this information [#SRC:297c1b5c-a066-4f82-b626-7572c7d5de26]. The Framework Contract must include information about the Payment Service Provider, the service itself, charges, communication methods, safeguards, contract changes, termination, and redress options, unless a different agreement is made in writing with a non-Natural Person [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b].

debug_context.source_text: If the Payment Service User so requests at any time during the term of the Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider must provide the information specified in Rule 19.2.1 as well as any other terms of the Framework Contract. Changes in contractual information
debug_context.target_text: Unless otherwise agreed in writing by a Payment Service Provider and a Payment Service User which is not a Natural Person in accordance with Rule 19.6.1, a Framework Contract between a Payment Service Provider and a Payment Service User must include the following information: (a) about the Payment Service Provider: (i) the name of the Payment Service Provider; (ii) the address and contact details of the Payment Service Providerâ€™s office in ADGM; (iii) the name of the Regulator of the Payment Service Provider, and details of the Payment Service Providerâ€™s Financial Service Permission; (b) about the Payment Service: (i) a description of the main characteristics of the Payment Service to be provided; (ii) the information or unique identifier that must be provided by the Payment Service User in order for a Payment Order to be properly initiated and executed; (iii) the form and procedure for giving consent to the initiation of a Payment Order or execution of a Payment Transaction and for the withdrawal of consent in accordance with Rule 19.10.1(3); (iv) the time of receipt of a Payment Order, in accordance with Rule 19.14.1, and the cut-off time for the processing of a Payment Order, if any, established by the Payment Service Provider; (v) the maximum execution time for the Payment Services to be provided; and (vi) any spending limits for the use of a Payment Instrument as agreed in accordance with Rule 19.10.2(1); (c) about charges and exchange rates: (i) details of all charges payable by the Payment Service User to the Payment Service Provider, including those connected to information which is provided or made available and, where applicable, a breakdown of the amounts of all charges; (ii) where relevant, details of the exchange rates to be applied or, if Reference Exchange Rates are to be used, the method of calculating the relevant date for determining such Reference Exchange Rates; (iii) where relevant and if agreed, the application of changes in Reference Exchange Rates and information requirements relating to any such changes, in accordance with Rule 19.2.5; (d) about communication: (i) the means of communication agreed between the parties for the transmission of information or notifications including, where relevant, any technical requirements for the Payment Service Userâ€™s equipment and software for receipt of the information or notifications; (ii) the manner in which and frequency with which information under Chapter 19 is to be provided or made available; (iii) the Payment Service Userâ€™s right to receive the revised terms of the Framework Contract and any other information in accordance with Rule 19.2.4; (e) about safeguards and corrective measures: (i) where relevant, a description of the steps that the Payment Service User must to take in order to keep safe a Payment Instrument and how to notify the Payment Service Provider of loss of the Payment Instrument for the purposes of Rule 19.11.1(3); (ii) how and within what period of time the Payment Service User must notify the Payment Service Provider of any unauthorised or incorrectly initiated or executed Payment Transaction under Rule 19.17.1; (iii) the secure procedure by which the Payment Service Provider will contact the Payment Service User in the event of suspected or actual fraud or security threats; (iv) where relevant, the conditions under which the Payment Service Provider proposes to reserve the right to stop or prevent the use of a Payment Instrument in accordance with Rule 19.14.2; (v) the Payerâ€™s liability under Rule 19.20.1 including details of any limits on such liability; (vi) the Payment Service Providerâ€™s liability for unauthorised Payment Transactions under Rule 19.20.1; (vii) the Payment Service Providerâ€™s liability for the initiation or execution of Payment Transactions under Rule 19.21.2 or Rule 19.21.3; and (viii) the conditions for the payment of any refund to the Payment Service User under this Chapter. (f) about changes to and termination of the Framework Contract: (i) where relevant, the proposed terms under which the Payment Service User will be deemed to have accepted changes to the Framework Contract in accordance with Rule 19.2.5, unless they notify the Payment Service Provider that they do not accept such changes before the proposed date of their entry into force; (ii) the duration of the Framework Contract; (iii) where relevant, the right of the Payment Service User to terminate the Framework Contract and any agreements relating to termination in accordance with Rule 19.2.8. (g) about redress: (i) any contractual clauses on the law applicable to the Framework Contract and the competent courts; and (ii) the availability of any alternative dispute resolution procedures, if applicable, for the Payment Service User and the methods for having access to them. (h) if the Payment Service involves the issuance of Stored Value, about the redemption of Stored Value, including the conditions of redemption and any related Fees.

question: What must a Fund Manager do to make sure the Fund Auditor's Report is correct, and how should the auditor's tasks be set?
expected_answer: A Fund Manager must instruct the auditor in writing to audit the Fund's financial statements according to the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB) guidelines [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579]. The Fund Manager also needs to ensure the Fund Auditor's Report includes checks on whether the financial statements are prepared correctly and show a true picture of the Fund's finances, including income and gains or losses [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce]. The auditor should confirm that the information in the Fund Manager's report matches the financial statements and that all necessary details for the audit were provided [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce].

debug_context.source_text: Function of the Auditor. A Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to: (a) conduct an audit of the Fund's financial statements in accordance with the requirements of the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB); and (b) produce a Fund Auditor's Report on the audited financial statements in accordance with GEN Rule 6.6.8.
debug_context.target_text: Fund Auditor's Report. A Fund Manager must, in procuring the production of a Fund Auditor's Report, ensure that an Auditor states: (1) whether the financial statements have been properly prepared in accordance with the financial reporting standards adopted by the Fund in accordance with FUNDS; (2) whether the financial statements give a true and fair view of the financial position of the Fund, including the net income and the net gains or losses of the Fund Property, or, as the case may be, the Fund Property attributable to the Sub-Fund for the annual accounting period in question and the financial position of the Fund or Sub-Fund as at the end of the annual accounting period; (3) whether proper accounting records for the Fund, or as the case may be, Sub-Fund, have not been kept, or that the financial statements are not in agreement with the accounting records and returns, or that the financial statements do not comply with the applicable financial reporting standards; (4) whether it has been given all the information and explanations which, to the best of its knowledge and belief, are necessary for the purposes of its audit; (5) whether the information given in the report of the Directors or in the report of the Fund Manager for that period is consistent with the financial statements; and (6) any other matter or opinion required by FUNDS.

question: What do firms need to do to manage risks, and how might their risk management be reviewed?
expected_answer: Firms need to set up and keep risk management systems that help them find, assess, reduce, control, and watch over their risks [#TGT:6f83c3c2-989d-47c2-952e-b1d8c7fb6c21]. These systems should also allow the firm to manage risks effectively, as external reviews can look at the firm's internal risk self-assessment to see how risks affect regulatory goals and how likely they are to happen [#SRC:f5c0b126-6b54-4fe9-9522-52952b6adad1].

debug_context.source_text: Review of risk management systems. Under GEN 3.3.4, a firm must ensure that its risk management systems provide the firm with the means to identify, assess, mitigate, monitor and control its risks. In addition to undertaking our own assessment of the firm, we may review the firm's internal risk self-assessment and determine the extent to which each of the firm's risks impact our objectives, the likelihood of the risk occurring, and the controls and mitigation programmes the firm has in place.
debug_context.target_text: Risk management: An Authorised Person must establish and maintain risk management systems and controls to enable it to identify, assess, mitigate, control and monitor its risks.

question: What must a Reporting Entity's Board say in their annual report about their Corporate Governance framework, and how does this relate to what a Listed Entity must report about adopting best practice standards?
expected_answer: A Reporting Entity's Board must state in their annual report if their Corporate Governance framework effectively meets the goals of section 73 of the FSMR and follows the Principles [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca]. This is related to a Listed Entity's requirement to report if they have adopted the best practice standards in APP 4 [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. If a Listed Entity hasn't fully adopted these standards, they must explain why and what steps they are taking to comply with the Corporate Governance Principles [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. Both must provide information and assumptions to support their statements [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca][#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e].

debug_context.source_text: General. The annual report required under Rule 9.2.10 must include a statement by the Board of Directors (the "Board"), stating whether or not, in its opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Reporting Entity is effective in achieving the outcome required by section 73 of the FSMR and promoting compliance with the Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary. As the Principles are the core of the Corporate Governance framework, the way in which they are applied should be the central question for the Board as it determines how the Reporting Entity conducts its affairs under its directorship in accordance with the letter and spirit of the applicable requirements including the Principles and the standards.
debug_context.target_text: Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must: (1) state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity; (2) if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain: (a) why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and (b) what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and (3) include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: Under what conditions must an Applicant ensure that its Shares satisfy the profits eligibility test when seeking admission to the Official List, and how does this relate to the market capitalisation requirement for Debentures?
expected_answer: An Applicant seeking to admit Shares to the Official List must ensure that the Shares satisfy the profits eligibility test if they do not meet the assets eligibility test [#SRC:7aa7740f-0ed0-4fd2-8217-d13529994838]. The profits eligibility test requires the Applicant to meet specific requirements, although these requirements are not detailed in the provided text [#TGT:f669df17-8f64-47cd-9622-aec87358f43c]. In contrast, if the application pertains to Debentures, the Applicant must ensure a Market Capitalisation of at least $2 million [#SRC:7aa7740f-0ed0-4fd2-8217-d13529994838].

debug_context.source_text: Market capitalisation. An Applicant must ensure that it, and the Securities which it seeks to admit to the Official List: (1) where the application relates to Shares, satisfy either the profits eligibility test in Rule 2.3.15 or the assets eligibility test in Rule 2.3.16; or (2) where the application relates to Debentures, have a Market Capitalisation of at least $2 million.
debug_context.target_text: Profits eligibility test. In order to meet the profits eligibility test, an Applicant must satisfy the following requirements.

question: When can the Regulator take away an Approval for a Controlled Function, and what things do they look at to decide if someone is fit and proper?
expected_answer: The Regulator can take away an Approval for a Controlled Function if they think the person is not fit and proper for the job [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554]. To decide this, they look at several things, like the rules in GEN 5.2.9 and section 2.3 of GPM about being fit and proper [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c]. They also check if the person has done anything dishonest or illegal, if other actions have been taken against them, what job they do, what the company does, where the company works, and how risky the person is to consumers and the financial system [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c].

debug_context.source_text: In determining whether to exercise our power under section 46 of FSMR, we will have regard to all relevant matters including, but not limited to: (a) the criteria for assessing the fitness and propriety of an Approved Person as set out in GEN 5.2.9 and section 2.3 of GPM; (b) the commission of any offences or a finding involving dishonesty, fraud or a financial crime by the Approved Person; (c) whether other enforcement action should be taken, or has already been taken, against the Approved Person by us or by other enforcement agencies; (d) the particular Controlled Function the Approved Person is or was performing; (e) the nature and activities of the firm concerned; (f) the markets in which the firm operates; and (g) the severity of the risk that the individual poses to consumers and to confidence in the ADGM financial system.
debug_context.target_text: Withdrawal of Controlled Function Approval The Regulator may withdraw an Approval given under section â€Ž45 if the Regulator considers that the person is not a fit and proper person to perform the Controlled Function in question.

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator disclose CRD Information originating from an EEA Competent Authority, and how does this relate to the requirements of the Capital Requirements Directive?
expected_answer: The Regulator may disclose CRD Information originating from an EEA Competent Authority only if specific conditions are met. Firstly, the EEA Competent Authority, defined as a public authority or body officially recognised by national law within the EEA and empowered to supervise institutions, must provide prior written consent for the disclosure [#SRC:dc3f77a8-19bb-49c7-a2f8-f257642a9321]. Additionally, if the consent is granted for a particular purpose, the Regulator must ensure that the disclosure is solely for that purpose [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c]. These conditions align with the professional secrecy requirements of the European Union's Capital Requirements Directive, ensuring that the exchange of information adheres to established confidentiality protocols [#SRC:dc3f77a8-19bb-49c7-a2f8-f257642a9321].

debug_context.source_text: The exceptions under section 199(1) of FSMR. The provisions in section 199(2) relate specifically to Confidential Information originating in another governmental or regulatory authority, or Confidential Information that is CRD Information, and provide for and are consistent with the exchange of information and professional secrecy requirements in the European Unions Capital Requirements Directive. For the purposes of section 199(2): (a) CRD Information is defined as Confidential Information received or obtained by the Regulator from the EEA Competent Authority by virtue of the Capital Requirements Directive; and (b) EEA Competent Authority means a public authority or body officially recognised by national law of a jurisdiction within the EEA and empowered by that national law to supervise institutions as part of the supervisory system.
debug_context.target_text: Paragraphs (1)(b)(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (vi) and 1(c) do not permit the Regulator to disclose Confidential Information unless the conditions in paragraphs (a) and (b) are met â€“ (a) where the Confidential Information (in whole or in part) originates in another governmental or regulatory authority, whether in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or otherwise, the authority that has disclosed the Confidential Information to the Regulator has given its prior written consent to the disclosure; and (b) where the Confidential Information is CRD Information â€“ (i) EEA Competent Authority that has disclosed the Confidential Information to the Regulator has given its prior written consent to the disclosure; and (ii) if such consent was given for a particular purpose, the disclosure by the Regulator is solely for that purpose.

question: What must a Mining Reporting Entity include when sharing financial forecasts and Ore Reserves, especially if some details are sensitive?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must include all important economic assumptions and other material assumptions when sharing financial forecasts [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. If any assumptions are sensitive, the entity should say so and explain how they were determined [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. For Ore Reserves, the entity needs to do a Technical Study, like a feasibility study, and share the main assumptions and results [#TGT:30cf9cda-951e-48ba-9be2-61a889a87464]. This helps ensure all necessary information is clear and complete.

debug_context.source_text: A Mining Reporting Entitys disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
debug_context.target_text: ORE RESERVES . Pursuant to Rule 11.6.1(1)(a), in order to achieve the required level of confidence in the modifying factors to determine an estimate of Ore Reserves, a Mining Reporting Entity will need to have carried out a relevant Technical Study (preliminary feasibility study or feasibility study ). The key underlying assumptions and outcomes of the Technical Study are also to be disclosed.

question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator issue a direction to a Recognised Body, and what consultation process must be followed before such a direction is given?
expected_answer: The Regulator may issue a direction to a Recognised Body when it appears that the Recognised Body has not taken action under its Default Rules, but could do so [#TGT:70b944a0-fca5-4266-8177-4fa3b31f8ea3]. Before giving such a direction, the Regulator must consult the Recognised Body in question [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a]. The Regulator must be satisfied, following this consultation, that failure to take action would involve undue risk to investors or other market participants, or that the direction is necessary for the public interest in financial stability within the Abu Dhabi Global Market [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a]. Additionally, the direction may be necessary to facilitate a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS or in connection with a particular exercise of a power under that chapter, or Rule 6.5.7(c) [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a].

debug_context.source_text: Before giving such a direction under Rule 6.5.4, the Regulator shall consult the Recognised Body in question, and the Regulator shall not give a direction unless the Regulator is satisfied, in the light of that consultation that: (a) failure to take action would involve undue risk to investors or other participants in the market; (b) the direction is necessary having regard to the public interest in the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or (c) the direction is necessary to facilitate a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS or in connection with a particular exercise of a power under that chapter, or Rule 6.5.7(c).
debug_context.target_text: The Regulator may issue a "positive" direction (to take action) where in any case a Recognised Body has not taken action under its Default Rules, but it appears to the Regulator that the Recognised Body could take action.

question: Under what conditions may an Authorised Person provide credit to a Related Person on terms more favourable than those available to non-Related Persons, and what procedural requirements must be met according to the Credit Risk policy?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person may provide credit to a Related Person on terms more favourable than those available to non-Related Persons if the credit is extended under an Employee credit policy that is widely available to Employees of the Authorised Person [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91]. This policy must be approved by the Authorised Person's Governing Body or its delegate and must clearly outline the terms, conditions, and limits for providing such credit [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91]. Additionally, the policy must include adequate mechanisms to ensure ongoing compliance, including immediate reporting to the Governing Body or its delegate in case of any deviations or breaches [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91]. Furthermore, if Exposures to Related Persons are allowed on terms no more favourable than those available to non-Related Persons, the policy must require prior written approval from the firm's Governing Body or its delegate for Exposures exceeding specific amounts or posing special risks [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496].

debug_context.source_text: Credit Risk policy. In relation to conflicts of interest and Related Person transactions, the policy must: (a) set out adequate procedures for handling conflicts of interest relating to the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person directly or indirectly benefiting from the credit being part of the process of granting or managing the credit; (b) subject to Rule 4.4.5, prohibit Exposures to Related Persons on terms that are more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons; and (c) if Exposures to Related Persons are allowed on terms which are no more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons, set out procedures that: (i) require such Exposures, and any write off of such Exposures, exceeding specific amounts or otherwise posing special risks to the Authorised Person, to be made subject to the prior written approval of the firm's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate; and (ii) exclude Persons directly or indirectly benefiting from the grant or write off of such Exposures being part of the approval process.
debug_context.target_text: Credit Risk policy. The prohibition in Rule 4.4.4(b) does not apply to Providing Credit to a Related Person under a credit policy on terms (such as for credit assessment, tenor, interest rates, amortisation schedules and requirements for Collateral) that are more favourable than those on which it provides credit to Persons who are not Related Persons, provided the credit policy: (a) is an Employee credit policy that is widely available to Employees of the Authorised Person; (b) is approved by the Authorised Person's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate; (c) clearly sets out the terms, conditions and limits (both at individual and aggregate levels) on which credit is to be provided to such Employees; and (d) requires adequate mechanisms to ensure on going compliance with the terms and conditions of that credit policy, including immediate reporting to the Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate where there is a deviation from or a breach of the terms and conditions or procedures applicable to the provision of such credit for timely and appropriate action.

question: How must a Reporting Entity demonstrate compliance with the Corporate Governance framework requirements under Section 73(2) of the FSMR, considering the Regulator's authority to prescribe principles and standards?
expected_answer: A Reporting Entity must demonstrate compliance with the Corporate Governance framework requirements under Section 73(2) of the FSMR by illustrating in its annual report how its actual practices align with the intended outcomes of prudent and sound management [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1]. The Regulator has the authority to prescribe specific Corporate Governance principles and standards, which may include requirements for the board of Directors, individual members, Controllers, employees, or any other relevant persons [#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d]. The Reporting Entity should ensure that these prescribed standards are reflected in its governance practices to meet the Regulator's expectations.

debug_context.source_text: General. Section 73(2) of the FSMR provides that the Regulator is entitled to enact rules requiring a Reporting Entity to have a Corporate Governance framework which is adequate to promote prudent and sound management of the Reporting Entity in the long term interest of the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders. Accordingly, in providing its explanation in the annual report as noted in 2, a Reporting Entity should aim to illustrate how its actual practices achieve compliance with the outcomes intended by section 73 of the FSMR and the Principles, and thereby contribute to prudent and sound management of the Reporting Entity.

question: Under what circumstances may the FSRA deem a digital/virtual token to be a Security, and how does this relate to the Regulator's power to deem investments as Securities?
expected_answer: The FSRA may deem a digital/virtual token to be a Security if it exhibits the economic and legal features and characteristics of a Security, as assessed on a case-by-case basis under the FSMR [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124]. This is in line with the Regulator's authority to deem any investment, which is not a Security, to be a Security for regulatory purposes, subject to terms and conditions it considers appropriate [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]. The FSRA's approach ensures investor protection by requiring a review of the token's characteristics, while the Regulator's power allows flexibility in regulatory classification.

debug_context.source_text: REGULATORY TREATMENT OF DIGITAL SECURITIES As set out in the ICO Guidance, the FSRAs assessment of whether an offering of a digital/virtual token is regulated under FSMR is conducted on a case-by-case basis (in keeping with FSRAs treatment of conventional Securities). If a digital/virtual token being offered is assessed to exhibit the (economic and legal) features and characteristics of a Security, the FSRA will deem the digital/virtual token (being a Digital Security) as a Security pursuant to Section 58(2)(b) of FSMR. This approach has been taken by the FSRA to ensure the protection of investors, noting that while a Digital Security may have the characteristics of a Security, this position is not always clear and accordingly requires review by the FSRA.
debug_context.target_text: Without limiting the generality of its powers, the Regulator may, by written noticeâ€” (a) exclude the application of any requirements; or (b) deem any investment which is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of these Regulations and the Rules made under these Regulations; subject to such terms and conditions as it may consider appropriate.

question: What capital ratios and requirements must a Domestic Firm follow to ensure it has enough capital?
expected_answer: A Domestic Firm must always have Capital Resources that meet or exceed its Capital Requirement [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e]. In addition, it must maintain certain capital ratios: the CET1 Capital must be at least 6.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount, the T1 Capital must be at least 8.0%, and the overall Capital Resources must be at least 10.0% [#SRC:f70e13d5-e8a2-464c-871c-7306c244548d]. These measures ensure the firm has sufficient capital to cover its risks.

debug_context.source_text: Capital ratios. Subject to 3.2.3, an Authorised Person must ensure that it complies with the following requirements at all times. (a) The ratio of CET1 Capital to Total Risk Exposure Amount must not be less than 6.0%. (b) The ratio of T1 Capital to Total Risk Exposure Amount must not be less than 8.0%. (c) The ratio of Capital Resources to Total Risk Exposure Amount must not be less than 10.0%. Guidance In Rule 3.16.2 CET1 Capital is that calculated at step A3, T1 Capital is that calculated at step A7 and Capital Resources is that calculated at step A11 of Rule 3.15.3.
debug_context.target_text: Domestic Firms â€“ adequate capital resources. An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must have, at all times, Capital Resources which equal or exceed the amount of its Capital Requirement.

question: Under what circumstances may the FSRA deem tokens in an ICO as Digital Securities, and how does the Regulator's power to deem investments as Securities apply in this context?
expected_answer: The FSRA may deem tokens in an ICO as Digital Securities if they exhibit characteristics of a Security, as assessed on a case-by-case basis under Section 58(2)(b) of FSMR [#SRC:1a404f4c-02fd-4447-956b-f17bb7b004dc]. In this context, the Regulator has the authority to deem any investment, which is not inherently a Security, to be a Security for regulatory purposes, subject to terms and conditions it considers appropriate [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]. This dual framework allows the FSRA to regulate ICOs effectively by leveraging its discretionary powers to classify tokens appropriately.

To this end, if the tokens in an ICO are assessed to exhibit the characteristics of a Security, FSRA may deem the tokens as a Security pursuant to Section 58(2)(b) of FSMR, hereinafter referred to as Digital Securities. Consequently, an issuer seeking to launch an ICO in or from ADGM should approach FSRA at the earliest opportunity.
debug_context.target_text: Without limiting the generality of its powers, the Regulator may, by written noticeâ€” (a) exclude the application of any requirements; or (b) deem any investment which is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of these Regulations and the Rules made under these Regulations; subject to such terms and conditions as it may consider appropriate.

question: What should a Listed Entity do in its annual report if it hasn't fully followed the Corporate Governance Principles, and how does Rule 9.2.10 relate to this?
expected_answer: If a Listed Entity has not fully followed the Corporate Governance Principles, it must explain why in its annual report and describe any steps taken to comply with these principles [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. This requirement is part of the 'comply or explain' approach outlined in Rule 9.2.10, which the Regulator uses for these principles [#SRC:ff77ddf9-257f-4e32-960f-cd1e696b8c72]. The report should also include a statement from the Directors about whether the governance framework effectively promotes compliance, with supporting details [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e].

debug_context.source_text: Rule 9.2.10 reflects the "comply or explain" approach adopted by the Regulator in respect of the Corporate Governance Principles.
debug_context.target_text: Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must: (1) state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity; (2) if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain: (a) why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and (b) what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and (3) include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: Under what circumstances must the Regulator immediately notify the Fund Manager of its decision not to transmit a notice, and what are the conditions that justify such a decision?
expected_answer: The Regulator is required to immediately notify the Fund Manager of its decision not to transmit a notice when it decides not to proceed under Rule 3.2.5 [#SRC:de227401-76fb-48e7-90c5-1fe0553a4657]. This decision is justified if the Regulator considers that the Fund Manager or the Public Fund does not comply with applicable legislation, or if there are reasonable grounds to determine potential future non-compliance [#TGT:02c6d009-e171-41d6-adac-aaaaf2b66e5a]. question: How must an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets reconcile Client Accounts, and what are the specific timing requirements compared to those conducting Investment Business?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person involved in a Regulated Activity related to Virtual Assets must perform reconciliations of Client Accounts with specific timing requirements: Rule 14.11.1 mandates weekly reconciliations, and Rule 14.11.4 requires reconciliations within five days of the relevant date [#SRC:3a1b6f65-bf51-4f78-840e-f64d67f67a52]. In contrast, an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must ensure reconciliations are performed at least every calendar month, supported by adequate systems and controls to maintain accuracy [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b].

debug_context.source_text: For the purposes of an Authorised Person that conducts a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets which holds or controls Client Money, the reconciliations of Client Accounts required under Section 14.11 shall be read as follows: (a) Rule 14.11.1 must be carried out at least every week; and (b) Rule 14.11.4 must be carried out within five days of the date to which the reconciliation relates.
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must maintain adequate systems and controls to ensure that accurate reconciliations of Client Accounts are carried out as regularly as necessary but at least every calendar month.

question: If an Authorised Person uses the FCCA, what counts as eligible financial Collateral, and how does it connect to Rule 4.13.5?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person using the FCCA must include as eligible financial Collateral any instrument from Rule 4.13.5, any equity Security traded on a regulated exchange, and any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund that invests in such equity Securities [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85]. The FCCA is based on Rule 4.13.6, differing from the FCSA, which follows Rule 4.13.5 [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19]. For a Collective Investment Fund's Units to be eligible, they must have a daily public price quote, and 90% of the Fund's assets must be in the specified instruments [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85].

debug_context.source_text: An Authorised Person must use either the: (a) Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.5 in relation to the composition of financial Collateral; or (b) Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA) which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.6; to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral.
debug_context.target_text: For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises: (a) any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5; (b) any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and (c) any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where: (i) a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and (ii) at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: If an Authorised Person doesn't meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, what must they do before making certain payments, and how does this relate to the maximum distributable amount?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that does not meet the Combined Buffer Requirement must first calculate the maximum distributable amount and notify the Regulator before making payments like distributions on CET1 Capital or on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]. Once this is done, they must ensure that any distributions do not exceed this calculated amount, as required by Rule 3.19.3(b) [#SRC:27f9bf56-82e3-4122-9d99-41e44b5fee9e].

debug_context.source_text: Restrictions on distributions. An Authorised Person must: (a) in subsequently taking any of the actions described in Rule 3.19.3(b)(i) and (ii), after having calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator, ensure that it distributes no more than its calculated maximum distributable amount; and (b) prepare and submit a capital conservation plan pursuant to Rule 3.19.9.
debug_context.target_text: Restrictions on distributions. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must: (a) calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6; and (b) ensure that it does not undertake any of the following actions until such time as it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7: (i) make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital, or create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, or pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement; or (ii) make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments.

question: How does Rule 9.3.4 interact with the HQLA requirement for an Authorised Person, particularly in maintaining liquidity under stress conditions?
expected_answer: Rule 9.3.4 establishes a minimum level requirement, which complements the broader mandate of Rule 9.3.3, ensuring that an Authorised Person maintains adequate liquidity [#SRC:749afea1-d63d-4350-83ca-1bc3e08aa551]. This aligns with the HQLA requirement that mandates an Authorised Person to always maintain sufficient High-Quality Liquid Assets (HQLA) to cover liquidity needs for at least 30 calendar days during a severe stress scenario [#TGT:93fbc822-3e3f-41ed-9356-02a43f97fcdc]. The conditions for assets to qualify as HQLA are detailed in Rules A10.2.2 to A10.2.9 in App10 [#TGT:93fbc822-3e3f-41ed-9356-02a43f97fcdc].

debug_context.source_text: Rule 9.3.4 sets a minimum level and is not intended to limit the generality of the requirement in Rule 9.3.3.
debug_context.target_text: HQLA requirement. An Authorised Person must at all times maintain an adequate level of HQLA to meet its liquidity needs for a minimum 30 calendar day period under a severe stress scenario. Rules A10.2.2 to A10.2.9 in App10 set out the conditions for assets to be treated as HQLA.

question: When a Specified Benchmark Information Provider also functions as a Price Reporting Agency, what additional compliance obligations must the Authorised Person fulfill under MIR Rule 3.11.2, considering the requirements for fair and non-discriminatory procedures in price establishment?
expected_answer: When a Specified Benchmark Information Provider also serves as a Price Reporting Agency, the Authorised Person is required to comply with the obligations outlined in MIR Rule 3.11.2, in addition to the specific rules under section 21.4 [#SRC:3af22e09-3d07-428f-8ca0-13b059f75329]. This includes ensuring that the Price Reporting Agency has fair and non-discriminatory procedures for establishing prices of a Financial Instrument, which must be made public [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. The agency must also demonstrate transparency in its methodology and calculations to allow users to understand how benchmarks or indices are derived, including any potential limitations [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a].

debug_context.source_text: Specified Benchmark Information Providers Price Reporting Agencies Where a Specified Benchmark Information Provider is also a Price Reporting Agency, the Authorised Person must comply with the requirements of MIR Rule 3.11.2, in addition to the Rules specified under this section 21.4.
debug_context.target_text: For the purposes of Rules 3.11.1 and 3.11.3, a Price Reporting Agency must: (a) have fair and non-discriminatory procedures for establishing prices of a Financial Instrument, which are made public; (b) demonstrate adequate and appropriate transparency over the methodology, calculation and inputs to allow users to understand how the benchmark or index is derived and its potential limitations; (c) where appropriate, give priority to concluded transactions in making assessments and adopt measures to minimise selective reporting; (d) be of good standing and repute as an independent and objective price reporting agency or index provider; (e) have a sound corporate governance framework; (f) have adequate arrangements to avoid its staff having any conflicts of interest where such conflicts are, or are likely to have, a material adverse impact on a price establishment process; and (g) adequate complaint resolution mechanisms to resolve any complaints about its assessment process and methodology.

question: What are the notification obligations of a Fund Manager of a Passported Fund regarding material events, and how does this relate to the Regulator's duty to inform the Host Regulator?
expected_answer: The Fund Manager of a Passported Fund is required to notify the Regulator as soon as practicable of any material events, such as changes in management or amendments to the Prospectus, and must do so no later than seven days after becoming aware of such events [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. Upon receiving such a notification, the Regulator is then obligated to notify the relevant Host Regulator of these changes without undue delay [#SRC:f1c064bd-93c8-459f-b7fa-fd9ed79b4669]. This process ensures that both the Regulator and the Host Regulator are kept informed of significant developments affecting the Passported Fund.

debug_context.source_text: Upon receiving such a notification as described in Rule 6.6.2, the Regulator shall without undue delay notify the relevant Host Regulator of such changes.
debug_context.target_text: The Fund Manager of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable of any material events, in accordance with applicable ADGM legislation. In particular (but without limitation), a Fund Manager or the governing body or trustee of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable (and in any case no later than seven days after it becomes aware) of any of the following events: (a) the Fund Manager intends to retire as manager of the Passported Fund; (b) it is proposed that a successor manager will be appointed in relation to the Passported Fund; (c) the Fund Manager has been removed or replaced as manager of the Passported Fund; (d) any material service provider to the Passported Fund (including, without limitation, any custodian) or an Agent or Licensed Person resigns, is appointed, is removed, or is replaced; (e) the Prospectus relating to the Passported Fund has been amended or replaced; (f) winding-up of the Passported Fund has commenced; or (g) the Fund Manager intends to vary or revoke its Financial Service Permission (or any conditions contained in that Financial Service Permission).

question: When does Price Stabilisation not break section 92, and how does it connect to Market Abuse rules?
expected_answer: Price Stabilisation does not break section 92 if it follows the rules in MKT 6.2, which are the specific guidelines for this activity [#SRC:6befa69b-50a0-463a-bf02-9fdaa4ed741e]. Also, if behaviour follows the Price Stabilisation Rules, it is not considered Market Abuse under these Regulations [#TGT:89c2648f-fb2a-4194-997f-a5d6d4f074a1]. So, following MKT 6.2 helps avoid breaking section 92 and protects against Market Abuse claims.

debug_context.source_text: Price Stabilisation. The effect of section 93(3)(b) is that if a Person establishes that they carried out Price Stabilisation in accordance with MKT 6.2, this conduct will not contravene section 92. MKT 6.2 sets out the relevant Rules relating to carrying on Price Stabilisation that must be complied with.
debug_context.target_text: Behaviour does not amount to Market Abuse for the purposes of these Regulations ifâ€” (a) it conforms with a Rule which includes a provision to the effect that Behaviour conforming with the Rule does not amount to Market Abuse; (b) it conforms with the Price Stabilisation Rules; or (c) it is done by a person acting on behalf of a public authority in the legitimate exercise of its public functions.

question: When can the Regulator stop an Approved Person from doing a Controlled Function, and how long can this stop last?
expected_answer: The Regulator can stop an Approved Person from doing a Controlled Function if it thinks the person has broken the Financial Services and Markets Regulations (FSMR) [#SRC:0e3409de-bae2-4891-a1dd-ef357ff5bb89][#TGT:5a34c2af-ed89-455c-8d46-645e7c8306d4]. This stop can last for as long as the Regulator decides is right [#SRC:0e3409de-bae2-4891-a1dd-ef357ff5bb89][#TGT:5a34c2af-ed89-455c-8d46-645e7c8306d4].

debug_context.source_text: In addition to the power to withdraw or vary an Approved Persons Approval (see paragraph 5.6), under section 233(2) of FSMR, we may suspend, for such period as we consider appropriate, an Approval given in relation to the performance of a Controlled Function. The Regulator may exercise this power in circumstances where it considers that the Approved Person has committed a contravention of FSMR.
debug_context.target_text: If the Regulator considers that an Approved Person has committed a contravention of these Regulations, it may suspend, for such period as it considers appropriate, any Approval of the performance by him of any Controlled Function to which the Approval relates.

question: Under what circumstances must the Listing Authority request a Disclosure from a Reporting Entity, and how is the subsequent response typically handled?
expected_answer: The Listing Authority must request a Disclosure from a Reporting Entity if, after an enquiry, it determines that the information is accurate, constitutes Inside Information, and is not exempt from Disclosure under Rule 7.2.2 [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944]. Once the Reporting Entity's response is received and reviewed, both the 'aware letter' and the response are typically Disclosed together by the Listing Authority. This ensures that the market in the Listed Entityâ€™s Securities is informed about the Listing Authority's enquiries regarding the timeliness of Disclosures and the Reporting Entity's response to those enquiries [#TGT:f4e70987-8287-425e-a207-54a123dfa6f4].

debug_context.source_text: SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY Complaints or allegations of non-compliance by Reporting Entities If, as a result of the enquiry, the Listing Authority forms the view that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within exemption from Disclosure provided by Rule 7.2.2, the Listing Authority will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter under Rule 7.2.1. If the information should have been Disclosed earlier, the Listing Authority may issue an aware letter (see paragraphs 187 to 189 above), or take other relevant action.
debug_context.target_text: SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY Aware Letters When a Reporting Entityâ€™s response has been received and reviewed by the Listing Authority, both the â€˜aware letterâ€™ and the Reporting Entityâ€™s response will usually be Disclosed together by the Listing Authority, so that the market in the Listed Entityâ€™s Securities is aware that the Listing Authority has made enquiries of the Reporting Entity about the timeliness of its Disclosures, and of the Reporting Entityâ€™s response to those enquiries.

question: How should an Authorised Person determine the risk weight for an unrated short term CR Exposure in the corporate asset class when the exposure has an issue-specific external credit assessment attracting a risk weight of 50% or 100%?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must apply a risk weight of not lower than 100% to any unrated short term CR Exposure to the same corporate if the issue-specific external credit assessment attracts a risk weight of 50% or 100% [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad]. This requirement is consistent with the general rule that unrated exposures in the corporate asset class are assigned a risk weight of 100% according to the table provided [#TGT:ee286214-80b1-480f-8be1-055c442795e4].

debug_context.source_text: Corporate asset class. The risk weight for any CR Exposure in the corporate asset class that does not have an external credit assessment by a recognised external credit rating agency must be the risk weight determined in accordance with the table under Rule 4.12.13 or the risk weight that is applicable to an CR Exposure to the central government of the jurisdiction in which the corporate is incorporated or established, whichever is higher. If a short term CR Exposure in the corporate asset class with an issue specific external credit assessment: (a) attracts a risk weight of 50% or 100%, then the Authorised Person must apply a risk weight of not lower than 100% to any unrated short term CR Exposure to the same corporate; or (b) attracts a risk weight of 150%, then the Authorised Person must apply a risk weight of 150% to any unrated CR Exposure (whether long term or short term) to the same corporate.
debug_context.target_text: Corporate asset class. Subject to Rules 4.12.14 and 4.12.15, an Authorised Person must risk weight any CR Exposure in the corporate asset class in accordance with the following table: Risk Weights for the corporate asset class /Table Start Credit Quality Grade 1 2 3 4 5 6 Unrated Risk Weight 20% 50% 100% 100% 150% 150% 100% /Table End

question: What steps must a Reporting Entity take to ensure compliance with Rule 7.2.1 when the Listing Authority cannot contact its designated points, and how does this relate to the preparation of disclosures?
expected_answer: A Reporting Entity must ensure that its designated contact points with the Listing Authority possess the necessary organisational knowledge and authority to address disclosure matters promptly. If the Listing Authority cannot contact these points, or if they lack the required authority, the Listing Authority may suspend the Listed Entity's Securities until the matter is resolved [#SRC:8fbe10b4-f49e-4b93-b470-a3c663f2ab94]. To manage disclosure obligations effectively, the Reporting Entity should have a template letter ready to request a Trading Halt urgently and ensure that relevant Officers have the authority to request a Trading Halt or Suspension and make a Disclosure as required [#TGT:40f90ce3-56d4-440a-abf9-2ab4b8249d8e].

debug_context.source_text: DISCLOSURES SYSTEMS, CONTROLS & CONTENT Other Reporting Entity steps to assist with compliance with Rule 7.2.1 The issue set out in paragraph 148h) above is most important, as the need to resolve a continuous disclosure matter may be extremely sensitive, and time critical. In circumstances where the Listing Authority is not able to contact the Reporting Entity (being the Reporting Entitys designated contact points with the Listing Authority), or the Reporting Entitys designated contacts do not have the organisational knowledge or authority to address the matter promptly, the Listing Authority may Suspend the Listed Entitys Securities until the matter is properly resolved.
debug_context.target_text: DISCLOSURES â€“ SYSTEMS, CONTROLS & CONTENT Other Reporting Entity steps to assist with compliance with Rule 7.2.1 Steps or actions that a Reporting Entity can take to help manage its disclosure obligations under Rule 7.2.1 include: a) To allow a Reporting Entity to urgently request a Trading Halt without delay, having a template letter ready for use at all times requesting the Listing Authority to grant a Trading Halt. b) Anticipating what might happen if the Inside Information leaks about a confidential transaction being negotiated, and have a template Disclosure ready that can be finalised and Disclosed straight away. c) Where it has advance notice of an event that is likely to require Disclosure under Rule 7.2.1, preparing a draft Disclosure ahead of time, allowing it to be Disclosed immediately. d) Where the event that gives rise to the need to make a Disclosure is within its control, being sensitive to the RIEâ€™s market (upon which the Listed Entityâ€™s Securities are admitted to trading) trading hours and, where possible, looking to ensure the event happens and the Disclosure is made before trading commences or after trading closes (so as to avoid any disruption to the normal course of trading of the Listed Entityâ€™s Securities of theâ€™RIE's market). e) Ensuring that it, and its relevant Officers responsible for communication with the Listing Authority, has the: (i) organisational knowledge to have relevant and meaningful discussions on Rule matters; and (ii) authority to request a Trading Halt or Suspension and make a Disclosure, if that is what is required under the Rules. f) Ensuring that it has appropriate arrangements in place to control, or deny, access to Inside Information (pursuant to Rules 7.2.7 to 7.2.9). The Listing Authority encourages efforts to keep the numbers of these â€˜insidersâ€™ to a minimum. g) Ensuring that it has in place arrangements for maintaining the confidentiality of Inside Information before Disclosure. These should include adequate training for Employees in the handling, distribution and announcement of Inside Information as appropriate. Reporting Entities should, for example, guard against the risk of Inside Information being leaked to the market through selective disclosure or otherwise. h) Ensuring that it is readily contactable by the Listing Authority by phone, and available to discuss any pressing Disclosure issues that arise, during the normal trading hours (on the RIE for which the Listed Entityâ€™s Securities are admitted to trading) and for at least one hour either side of the RIEâ€™s normal trading hours each Business Day.

question: Under what conditions is information considered 'Inside Information' for Financial Instruments, and how does the concept of 'generally available' information apply?
expected_answer: Information is considered 'Inside Information' for Financial Instruments if it is of a precise nature and not generally available, relates directly or indirectly to Reporting Entities or Issuers, and would likely have a significant effect on the price if it were generally available [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977]. The term 'generally available' is not explicitly defined in the FSMRs, but information that can be obtained through research or analysis by market users is regarded as generally available to them [#SRC:5107d7d4-642e-466e-a4c5-17377a88b6af].

debug_context.source_text: When is information "generally available"? Information is only "Inside Information" under the definition in section 95(2) if it is not generally available and has not been made available to the public. The FSMRs do not define what is meant by "generally available", although section 95(8) states that information which can be obtained by research or analysis conducted by, or on behalf of, users of a market is to be regarded as being "generally available" to them.

question: When can an Investigator go into a business to look at and copy documents, and what must a Person Under Investigation do if they get a written notice?
expected_answer: An Investigator can enter a business to inspect and copy documents if it is important for an investigation, as allowed by Section 206(1)(e) of FSMR [#SRC:6f288073-515c-4e53-9fa5-16c3700d2767]. If a Person Under Investigation receives a written notice, they must allow the Investigator to enter their business during normal hours to look at and copy documents [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. This ensures that the Investigator can access the needed documents either directly or through cooperation.

debug_context.source_text: Power to enter premises and inspect and copy documents . Section 206(1)(e) of FSMR permits the Investigator to enter business premises for the purpose of inspecting and copying any documents where relevant for the purposes of the investigation.
debug_context.target_text: The Investigator may, by written notice, require the person who is the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation) toâ€” (a) attend an interview at a Specified time and place and answer questions; (b) produce at a Specified time and place any Specified Documents or Documents of a Specified description; (c) provide such information as the Investigator may require; (d) provide such assistance as the Investigator may require; or (e) permit the Investigator to enter the business premises of such person during normal business hours for the purpose of inspecting and copying Documents on such premises.

question: What must an Applicant do when applying for a listing, including document submission and other steps?
expected_answer: An Applicant must submit all documents listed in Rule 2.4.1 to the Regulator's address [#SRC:0cd75f80-4564-41c1-aa7d-5303022d6e69]. They must also ensure these documents are in the final form and follow the Regulator's prescribed format [#TGT:51448452-8fa0-4ada-97cb-b76691244d25]. The Applicant needs to pay the fee specified in the FEES Rulebook when submitting the application [#TGT:51448452-8fa0-4ada-97cb-b76691244d25]. Additionally, they must provide any extra documents, explanations, and information required by the Regulator, including those in Rules 2.4.4 and 2.4.5 [#TGT:51448452-8fa0-4ada-97cb-b76691244d25]. Verification of the information must be submitted as specified by the Regulator [#TGT:51448452-8fa0-4ada-97cb-b76691244d25].

debug_context.source_text: Listing application. All the documents in Rule 2.4.1 must be submitted to the Regulator at the Regulator's address.
debug_context.target_text: Listing application. An Applicant must apply to the Regulator by: (1) submitting in final form the relevant documents in such form as the Regulator shall prescribe; (2) paying the fee set out in the FEES Rulebook at the time of submission of the completed application form; (3) submitting all additional documents, explanations and information as may be required by the Regulator, including the documents specified in Rules 2.4.4 and 2.4.5; and (4) submitting verification of any information in such manner as the Regulator may specify.

question: Under what conditions must an Authorised Person maintain a Trading Book, and what are the requirements for differentiating between Trading Book and Non Trading Book activities?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person is required to maintain a Trading Book if it holds positions that must be included in a Trading Book as per Section A2.1 of App2, and these positions are held with trading intent in accordance with Rule A2.1.5 [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0]. Additionally, the total value of these positions must normally exceed $15 million or 5% of its combined on and off balance sheet positions, or have exceeded $20 million or 6% of its combined on- and off balance sheet positions at any time in the preceding 12 months [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0]. Once these conditions are met, the Authorised Person must comply with the requirements of Section A2.1 of App2 and consistently differentiate its business between Trading Book activity and Non Trading Book activity [#SRC:aba54eac-db1f-431a-be16-6e410fca8f27].

debug_context.source_text: An Authorised Person that must have a Trading Book in accordance with Rule 2.2.1 must: (a) comply with the requirements of Section A2.1 of App2; and (b) differentiate its business between Trading Book activity and Non Trading Book activity on a consistent basis.
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person must have a Trading Book if: (a) it has positions that must be included in a Trading Book in accordance with Section A2.1 of App2; (b) those positions are held with trading intent in accordance with Rule A2.1.5; and (c) the total value of the positions eligible for inclusion in the Trading Book pursuant to (a) and (b): (i) normally exceeds $15 million or 5% of its combined on and off balance sheet positions; or (ii) has exceeded $20 million or 6% of its combined on- and off balance sheet positions at any time in the preceding 12 month period.
